description.original_text: Cultural and historical tour from Dakar to, Goree Island, the Pink Lake, and Abuja Nature Reserve. Also relax at Saly and enjoy water sports, beach and great cuisine. Spend a few days in The Gambia visiting sites in Banjul, Serekunde, and Bakau. Visit markets, artisans, museums and more.

website_content.original_text: Senegal & GambiaAlex Haley’s book, Roots, is focused on The Gambia. In Senegal you must visit Goreé Island, a departure point for many Africans who were sold into slavery. The Door of No Return is the museum preserving its history. Cultural villages, forests, festivals, birdlife and one of the best cuisines in West Africa.

website_content.original_text: GambiaSe alla länderÖversiktHotellFaktaVäderRestipsBildgalleri(1/44)Bildgalleri(1/44)Under din resa till solsäkra Gambia kan du se fram emot avkopplande dagar fyllda med sol och bad på de långa och härliga sandstränderna. Utforska den rika kulturen och upplev de färgstarka och livliga marknaderna. Gambia hälsar dig välkommen med allt som behövs för en avkopplande, upplevelserik och minnesvärd semester!Populära hotell - GambiaSe allaKombo Beach ResortGambiaPer person från 11 089 krCape Point HotelGambiaPer person från 9 195 krBalafon Beach ResortGambiaPer person från 11 093 krBungalow BeachGambiaPer person från 9 512 krMer om resmåletDen vänliga lokalbefolkningen hälsar dig varmt välkommen till Gambia, även känt som "the smiling coast". Hit har semesterfirande skandinaver rest sedan 1960-talet för att uppleva allt från soldränkta stränder och spännande utflykter till lokala marknader och det genuina vardagslivet.Gambia ligger i västra Afrika, öster om Kap Verde och delar gräns med Senegal som omger landet förutom längs kustlinjen.Långa sandstränderSe fram emot avslappnat strandhäng och lata dagar i solstolen på någon av Gambias härliga och kilometerlånga stränder. De finkorniga sandstränderna är både många och stora - perfekt för dig som vill breda ut dig och slippa trängas. Under eftermiddagen när temperaturen sjunkit något samlas människor på stranden för att spela fotboll, promenera eller bara njuta av den vackra solnedgången.På söndagar beger sig lokalbefolkningen till stranden för en dag fylld av umgänge och avkoppling. Picknickkorgar packas och stranden blir en samlingsplats där människor umgås, badar, spelar fotboll och äter mat tillsammans.Sevärdheter & naturupplevelserGambia är mycket mer än bara långa sandstränder! Utforska landets fantastiska djur- och naturliv som sträcker sig lång bortom kustremsan. Vad sägs om att ta en båttur på Gambiafloden och spana in flodhästarna i sin naturliga miljö eller varför inte upptäcka det rika fågellivet i de imponerande mangroveträsken?Vill du upptäcka det autentiska Gambia rekommenderar vi ett besök på den spännande landsbygden. Där kan du utforska lokala marknader och det vardagliga livet.Restauranger och nöjeslivNjut av god mat på någon av alla lokala och internationella restauranger. Prova några av de lokala rätterna Benachin, en ris- och skaldjursrätt eller den populära chili- och jordnötsgrytan, Domada.Gambia erbjuder även ett brett utbud av riktigt bra libanesiska restauranger, så passa på att utforska det utsökta libanesiska köket under sin semester.När det kommer till nattklubbar och barer finns allt från enkla strandbarer, trevliga loungebarer till livliga nattklubbar som har öppet till långt in på småtimmarna.Apollos hotell & resmål i GambiaPå många av våra resmål runt om i världen kan du bo längs med stranden, men i Gambia bor du bokstavligen på stranden!Reser du till Gambia med Apollo har du möjlighet att välja bland flera fina hotell och områden längs den vackra Atlantkusten. Vill du bo ”där det händer” rekommenderas våra hotell i Kololi och speciellt området Senegambia som bjuder på en livfull atmosfär med ett uttalat nöjesliv, ett brett utbud av restauranger som erbjuder allt från libanesisk till italiensk mat, och många trevliga barer.I Kotu-området väntar en av Gambias finaste stränder och trots att flera hotell ligger vid stranden finns det gott om plats för alla. För de som vill bo med bästa strandläge är sporthotellet Kombo Beach Resort ett utmärkt val, här trivs både träningsentusiaster och barnfamiljer, som båda kan njuta av hotellets många bekvämligheter och aktiviteter. I Kotu finns också ett par restauranger, små butiker och mysiga barer att utforska.I området Cape Point bor du nära både stranden och det lokala livet, vilket ger dig möjlighet att upptäcka och handla färsk frukt och hantverk på de lokala marknaderna. För en extra lugn och avslappnad semester rekommenderar vi området Bijilo, bortom Gambias lite större turistområden. Här kan du ta dagen som den kommer och se fram emot sköna dagar i solstolen.Utflykter med ApolloVill du upptäcka mer av Gambia har du även möjligheten att följa med på flera av våra härliga och spännande utflykter som finns bokningsbara på Mitt Apollo. Du kan bland annat följa med till naturparken Senegal Fathala Park, där du kan få se giraffer, zebror och noshörningar. Lär du dig hellre mer om den lokala maten kan du följa med på en matlagningskurs.Fakta om GambiaTidsskillnadSvensk tid -1 timme vintertid, svensk tid -2 timmar sommartid.ValutaDalasi (GMD). I Gambia är det viktigt att ha kontanter med sig då kortbetalning inte accepteras överallt. Det är möjligt att växla pengar i de flesta hotellreceptioner, men för en bättre växlingskurs rekommenderas att besöka växlingskontoren runt omkring, det finns många. Det finns också växlingskontor på flygplatsen. Vill du ta ut kontanter på plats finns även flera uttagsautomater runt om i området.Transfer till resmåletTransfer från flygplatsen till Apollos hotell tar ca 45 minuter.StränderStränderna i Gambia är både breda och flera kilometerlånga med härligt finkornig sand. Notera att undervattensströmmar kan förekomma och vi rekommenderar att du inte simmar allt för långt ut. På stränderna längs Atlantkusten kan även större vågor förekomma. Håll koll på flaggorna på stränderna för att se om det är säkert att bada.VäderServicenivåApollo Service LinePå resmål med Apollo Service Line kan du, dygnet runt, komma i kontakt med oss via telefon, sms och mejl, som besvaras av skandinavisk- och engelsktalande Apollo personal. Är ärendet brådskande bör kontakten alltid ske via telefon.Reser du med ett flyg i reguljärtrafik och har beställt transfer så blir du mött av en lokal representant som hjälper dig till hotellet. Aktuellt telefonnummer till Apollo Service Line får du via sms kort inpå din utresa.Vi älskar era semesterbilder!Vill du synas här? Tagga dina bilder och reels på Instagram med @apollosverige

description.original_text: Gambia birding tours are seen as great introduction to African birding and will surely leave you yearning for more from this amazing birding and wildlife

marketing_content.original_text: Gambia Birding Tours Download Gambia Itineraries Gambia Gallery Testimonials from our Gambia birding tours Gambia: Winter Escape Birdwatching Holiday January 2026/2027

website_content.original_text: Gambia Birding Tours Go to: Senegal birding tours | Birding tours to Africa and its islands | All our Birding Tours Gambia birding tours are seen as a great introduction to African birding and will surely leave you yearning for more from this amazing birding and wildlife continent. The Republic of The Gambia (“The Gambia” hereafter) is the smallest country of mainland Africa. The entire country is surrounded by Senegal, except for the west coast which sits on the Atlantic Ocean. The Gambia really is a tiny country at just 4,127 square miles (10,689 square kilometers) which would make it the third smallest mainland US state, just behind Connecticut. The Gambia’s population is around 2.2 million people, about the same as New Mexico, with around 413,000 people living within the urban area of the capital, Banjul. Banjul is a relatively modern city, only being founded in 1816, and was the center when The Gambia was a colony of the British Empire. The first records of The Gambia are from the 9th and 10th centuries when the area was visited by Arab traders from North Africa. Later The Gambia became part of the Mali Empire, before the Portuguese Empire arrived and sold the trade rights of The Gambia to the British Empire, ruled by Queen Elizabeth I. During the 17th century the British Empire and French Empire fought for control of the region before Britain finally invaded and occupied the country in 1758. While France retained some control, what remained was ceded to Britain in 1856. The modern boundaries of The Gambia were formed in 1889 and The Gambia finally gained independence from Britain in 1963. Read More About Gambia During the three centuries of the transatlantic slave trade, it is thought that as many as three million people were transported from The Gambia and the surrounding region to colonies across the world. In 1807 the British Empire abolished the slave trade but failed in doing this in The Gambia until 1906. The geography of the Gambia is dominated by The Gambia River which flows down the spine of the country. The surrounding land is flat and a mixture of savanna, forest-savanna, and mangroves. The Gambia is only 31 miles (50 kilometers) wide at its widest point and as such the climate is consistent across the country. The tropical climate brings rain between June and November along with high temperatures. From November until May the climate is dry, and temperatures are lower. The Gambia’s bird list is currently 620 species (following International Ornithological Congress (IOC) taxonomy v11.1 in May 2021), an incredible total for such a small country. There are obviously far too many species to list here but some of the many highlight species from our The Gambia: Gateway to Africa tour include Egyptian Plover (a most-wanted bird for many world birders and a monotypic family), African Paradise Flycatcher, African Pygmy Goose, Hamerkop (another monotypic family), Guinea Turaco, Violet Turaco, Northern Carmine Bee-eater, Swallow-tailed Bee-eater, Oriole Warbler, White-spotted Flufftail, African Finfoot, Abyssinian Ground Hornbill, Martial Eagle, African Fish Eagle, Bateleur, Red-necked Falcon, Marabou Stork, Pygmy Sunbird, Exclamatory Paradise Whydah, Black Crowned Crane, Long-tailed Nightjar, Blue Malkoha, Green-headed Sunbird, White-crested Helmetshrike, Splendid Starling, White-breasted Cuckooshrike, Grey-headed Kingfisher, Pel’s Fishing Owl, African Wood Owl, Greyish Eagle-Owl, Verreaux’s Eagle-Owl, White-backed Night Heron, Spotted Honeyguide, Bronze-winged Courser, Red-throated Bee-eater, Four-banded Sandgrouse, Stone Partridge, and much more. We will also come across a wide range of Western Palearctic migrants during our Gambia birding tour including many passerines, shorebirds (waders), herons, bitterns, egrets, birds of prey, and swifts. It promises to be a wonderful birding experience. This Gambia birding tour is designed to be the perfect introduction to African birding. We will be staying in the famous Senegambia Beach Hotel during our time on the coast which offers all the facilities of the best hotels in Europe. With the bonus of around 230 species of birds recorded in the hotel grounds and immediate area, it also allows for excellent photo opportunities. When we travel upriver, we will stay in comfortable and safe eco-lodges with the birds again on our doorstep, and while on our journey we make use of safe and comfortable vehicles. Gambia: Winter Escape Birdwatching Holiday January 2026/2027 View More Download Gambia ItinerariesGambia: Winter Escape Birdwatching Holiday January 2026/2027Gambia Gallery View Larger Egyptian Plover View Larger Abyssinian Ground Hornbill View Larger Black-faced FirefinchMattias Hofstede View Larger African Finfoot View Larger Goliath Heron View Larger Bateleur View Larger Hamerkop View Larger Northern Carmine Bee-eater View Larger Pel's Fishing Owl View Larger Palm-nut Vulture View Larger Saddle-billed Stork View Larger White-crowned Lapwing View Larger Swallow-tailed Bee-eater View Larger African Fish Eagle View Larger Black HeronMattias Hofstede View Larger Spotted HoneyguideMattias Hofstede View Larger White-crested Helmetshrike View Larger Martial Eagle View Larger Yellow-crowned Gonolek View Larger Senegal Parrot Testimonials from our Gambia birding tours Senegal and The Gambia is a delightful destination and is full of birds. For those that have not experienced Africa before, it is an excellent introduction to African birding. The river trips are wonderful and it is difficult to know where to look first with bee-eaters, kingfishers of multi colors assaulting the mind. Dylan is a very able leader whom we enjoy travelling with as his African birding knowledge is first class as well as having a delightful personality well able to overcome problems that inevitably arise in African countries. The climate of sun and heat is a welcome relief of grey, cold miserable weather experienced in the northern hemisphere in winter. Accommodation is basic but adequate and local eateries are interesting but would not win any medals for hygiene. Sue - On Senegal/The Gambia and Dylan - December 2022

Over Gambia Foto's & video Home Gambia Kalimba Beach Resort Balafon Beach Resort Ocean Bay Vakantie Gambia: ‘the Smiling Coast of Africa’ De altijd stralende zon, kleurrijke bevolking en het exotische natuurschoon maken van Gambia een geweldige vakantiebestemming. Gambia staat beter bekend als ‘the Smiling Coast of Africa’. En dat is niet zonder reden! Ontdek zelf de tropische stranden, oprechte gastvrijheid en de culturele pracht van Afrika en boek nu je vakantie Gambia bij Corendon! Goedkope vakantie Gambia Hoewel Gambia het kleinste land van Afrika is, heeft het een grootse natuurlijke schoonheid. De 70 kilometer lange kustlijn met hagelwitte zandstranden is alleen al een goede reden om voor een vakantie Gambia te kiezen. Heerlijk zonnen op het strand, relaxen met een cocktail in je hand… Maar Gambia biedt veel meer dan zon, zee en strand. Trek ook het binnenland in en bewonder de uitgestrekte mangrovebossen waar onder andere meer dan 450 verschillende soorten vogels leven. Gambia vakantie informatie Weer Gambia Gambia is een tropisch vakantieparadijs met warm zeewater, wuivende palmbomen en ruim 7 tot 8 uur zon per dag. Van november tot en met mei kun je tijdens een vakantie Gambia genieten van een gemiddelde temperatuur van 21 tot 27 graden. En de zon, die schijnt het hele jaar door! Het is dan ook niet zo vreemd dat Gambia een geliefde winterzonbestemming is. Bekijk onze uitgebreide informatie over het klimaat van gambia. Gambia bezienswaardigheden Varen over ‘The Gambia’ De belangrijkste toeristische attractie van Gambia is de gelijknamige rivier ‘The Gambia’. Deze rivier is de levensader van Gambia en stroomt over de volledige lengte van het land. Het is een absolute must om een boottocht te maken tijdens je vakantie Gambia. Het water wordt omzoomd door de groene jungle, waar je vogels en misschien zelfs ook nijlpaarden of krokodillen kunt spotten. Afdingen op de markt in Banjul Wil je het echte Gambiaanse leven proeven? Doe dan je boodschappen op de markt! Struin door smalle straatjes met zelfgemaakte kraampjes en tik bijzondere souvenirs op de kop. Je kunt het zo gek niet bedenken of het is te koop: etenswaren, kleding, witgoed… Aanraders om te bezoeken tijdens je vakantie Gambia zijn de Albert Market in Banjul of de Serrekunda Market in Serrekunda. Hotels en Appartementen in Gambia Corendon heeft een gevarieerd aanbod aan appartementen en hotels in Gambia. Corendon heeft alle accommodaties met grote zorg geselecteerd om je vakantie Gambia zo aangenaam mogelijk te maken. Bij de selectie van de accommodaties wordt onder andere gelet op de ligging t.o.v. stranden, eetgelegenheden en eventuele stadscentra. lees meer Kaart Vluchtinfo 7,7 Gem cijfer, 2296 beoordelingen va. Bekijk deze vakantie Annie - Productmanager Gambia "Gambia, oftewel ‘The smiling coast of Africa’! Ik geniet hier van de uiterst vriendelijke mensen die altijd vrolijk en gezellig zijn en in harmonie met elkaar leven. Heerlijk uiteten op de Strip en vervolgens een dansje wagen met de ritmische Gambianen. Tip: bezoek het binnenland tijdens een excursie om het echte Gambia te ontdekken." Gerelateerd Meer vakanties in Gambia Alle vakanties Gambia Luxe vakantie Gambia All Inclusive Gambia Last minute Gambia Hotels Gambia Gambia met kinderen Algemene informatie Hoofdstad: Banjul Aantal inwoners: 1.883.051 (2013) Oppervlakte: 11.295 km2 Taal: Engels Religie: 90% Islamitisch, 9% Christelijk Tijdsverschil: 2 uur vroeger in de zomer, 1 uur vroeger in winter Munteenheid: Dalasi Regeringsvorm: Republiek Elektriciteit: 220V, 50 hertz wisselstroom BNP per hoofd: $2.000 (2011) Landnummer: +220 Lokale noodnummers: Ambulance 116, politie 117, brandweer 118 Eten en drinken In de vakantiegebieden zijn de meeste restaurants helemaal op de toeristen ingesteld. Je hebt er keuze uit allerlei restaurants, van Chinees tot Mexicaans. In de steden kun je heel goedkoop Afrikaans eten, maar wees voorzichtig en let goed op de hygiëne! Men gebruikt in Gambia veel rijst, kip en vis, bereiding geschiedt meestal op een vuur. Het water dat in Gambia uit de kraan komt is in veel hotels van redelijk goede kwaliteit, maar het drinken ervan wordt afgeraden. Daarom is ons advies om flessen mineraalwater te kopen. Een van de weinige fabrieken in Gambia is de Banyul Brewery, hier wordt het goed drinkbare Gambiaanse bier Julbrew (groene flesjes) gebrouwen. Taal Engels is de officiële taal in Gambia, met name bij de overheid, in het onderwijs, in de rechtspraak en natuurlijk in de toeristencentra. Ruim de helft van de Gambianen spreekt naast Engels een eigen stamtaal.Natuur Gambia is een paradijs voor vogelliefhebbers. Er werden tot nu toe ongeveer 450 verschillende soorten geteld, en nog steeds worden nieuwe soorten ontdekt. Helaas zijn alle grote zoogdieren vrijwel allemaal uitgestorven door de jacht die in de 19 de eeuw op ze gemaakt werd. De welbekende 'African Big Five' zal je in Gambia niet vinden want olifanten, neushoorns, giraffen, leeuwen, buffels, grote antilopen, hebben hun heil ergens anders gezocht. Diep landinwaarts komen nog wel nijlpaarden en krokodillen in de Gambia rivier voor. Verschillende kleine apensoorten zoals de fluweelaap en de huzaaraap komen overal voor. Chimpansees leven alleen nog in het Baboon Island National park. Verder zijn er nog kleine antilopensoorten, aardvarkens en wrattenzwijnen. Gambia heeft een aantal nationale parken en reservaten waar deze dieren te bewonderen zijn.Feestdagen 1 januari: Nieuwjaar 14 februari: Onafhankelijkheidsdag 27 februari: Hemelvaart Mohammed (Isra en Mi'raj) 28 februari – 30 maart: Ramadan 8 maart: Internationale Vrouwendag 30 maart: Suikerfeest (Eid al-Fitr) 6 juni: Offerfeest (Eid al-Adha) 5 september: Geboortedag Mohammed (Milad un-Nabi) 25 & 26 december: Kerstmis 31 december: OudjaarAchtergrond / Geschiedenis De vroegste schriftelijke verwijzing naar Gambia is vastgelegd in het verslag van Hanno de Carthaag. De Carthagen leefden ongeveer 470 voor Christus in het oude Europa / Middellandse Zeegebied en maakten vele intercontinentale reizen en stonden zo in contact met verre beschavingen. Het eerste Portugese contact met Gambia werd gelegd in 1456 toen een Portugese verkenningsvloot op het huidige James Island landde. Zij vestigden handelsposten waar zij zout, ijzer, buskruit en geweren verhandelden in ruil voor ivoor, goud, ebbenhout en slaven. Begin 17e eeuw kampten de Portugese kolonies in Brazilië met een arbeiderstekort, wat er toe leidde dat dit tekort aangevuld werd vanuit West Afrika door middel van slaven. Hierna volgden de Nederlanders en de Fransen het voorbeeld waardoor Portugal zijn monopolistische positie verloor. De slaven werden tewerkgesteld in onder andere Amerika, Jamaica , Suriname en de Antillen. In 1661 namen de Britten definitief bezit van James Island en dit was het begin van de Britse heerschappij over Gambia. De Fransen namen bezit van wat tegenwoordig Senegal is. Pas in 1807 werd onder Britse heerschappij de slavernij afgeschaft, maar de Britten bleven Gambia wel bezetten. Na de Tweede Wereld Oorlog kwamen er steeds meer stemmen voor zelfbeschikking, maar pas op 18 februari 1965 kreeg Gambia politieke onafhankelijkheid van Groot-Brittannië. Op 24 april 1970 werd Gambia een zelfstandige republiek. Duurzamer op vakantie Écht duurzame vliegvakanties bestaan helaas nog niet. Maar als je je voetafdruk een (klein) beetje wilt verkleinen, kun je bij het boeken van je vliegvakantie Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) kopen. Wat dat precies is lees je hier. Met het kopen van SAF draag je bij aan een lagere CO2-uitstoot van je vliegreis. Je kunt daarnaast kiezen voor een gecertificeerde accommodatie. Deze hotels voldoen aan de hoogste duurzaamheidsstandaarden en zijn daarom een betere keuze voor je vakantie. Maak je gebruik van een transfer naar je hotel? Gemiddeld genomen vervoert een bus meer mensen dan een taxi, waardoor de CO2-uitstoot per passagier lager wordt. Een bustransfer is daarom vaak een duurzamere keuze dan een privétransfer. Op de bestemming Gambia ligt aan de westkust van Afrika en is volledig ingesloten door Senegal. De natuurlijke omgeving van Gambia wordt gekenmerkt door de Gambia-rivier die dwars door het land stroomt. Langs de rivier en de zee vind je mangroves en een overvloed aan vogel- en vissoorten. De mangroves zijn belangrijk, want ze vormen natuurlijke barrières tegen bodemerosie. Het is belangrijk om je te realiseren dat Gambia een land is dat voor grote uitdagingen staat als het gaat om natuurbescherming, armoede en gelijke rechten. Als je Gambia bezoekt, zal je zien dat er veel afval langs de weg ligt en dat mensen in armoedige huizen of op straat leven. Het kan daarom even schakelen zijn als je uit het vliegtuig stapt. Maar de meeste Gambianen zullen je met open armen ontvangen. In Gambia zijn de meeste mensen moslim. De vrouwen zijn vaak gesluierd. Het is respectvol om zelf ook bedekkende kleding te dragen, vooral als je de toeristische gebieden uit gaat. Muziek en dans spelen een centrale rol in het Gambiaanse leven en lokale festivals en vieringen zijn vaak gevuld met traditionele muziek en kleurrijke dansuitvoeringen. Schroom niet om zelf mee te dansen, de Gambianen zijn vriendelijk en verwelkomen je graag. Bewust op excursie Hoewel je op onze bestemmingen tal van avontuurlijke excursies en activiteiten kunt ondernemen, is het belangrijk om je bewust te zijn van de mogelijke impact ervan op de natuur en cultuur. Over het algemeen geldt: zo lang je mensen, dieren en natuur respectvol behandelt, kun je met een gerust hart van je vakantie genieten. Klik hier voor een overzicht van handige do's en don'ts tijdens excursies. De Gambiaanse mangroves kun je het beste bewonderen vanuit een kayak. Er zijn verschillende nature reserves die je in Gambia of het naastgelegen Senegal kunt bezoeken. Ook een batikworkshop is een aanrader: hier leer je hoe typisch Afrikaanse stoffen worden bedrukt. Als je meer wilt leren over de geschiedenis van het land kun je James Island en het Fort James bezoeken. Het binnenland van Gambia geeft een andere kijk op het land. Spreek een lokale taxichauffeur aan om je erheen te brengen en je de mooiste plekjes te laten zien. Maatschappelijke impact Er zijn verschillende manieren om de lokale bevolking of de natuur op je vakantiebestemming te helpen of te ondersteunen. Vraag je lokale reisleiding naar zijn of haar tips voor goede doelen of sociale initiatieven. Iedere bestemming heeft namelijk eigen uitdagingen op het gebied van klimaat of maatschappelijke kwesties. Corendon steunt in Gambia de Bakau Basketball Academy (BBA): een plek waar jongeren iedere dag van de week samen kunnen sporten onder begeleiding van twee oud-profbasketballers. Veel kinderen in de achterstandswijken van Banjul missen rolmodellen in hun directe omgeving. Dankzij de BBA hebben ze de nodige afleiding en krijgen ze perspectief. De Nederlandse Ed Spier reisde al vier keer op onze kosten naar Gambia om de BBA te helpen groeien. Vluchtduur De vluchtduur naar de luchthaven van Banjul bedraagt ca. 6.15 uur. Bekijk de vliegtijd naar Gambia. Je dient er rekening mee te houden dat de hierboven genoemde vluchttijd slechts ter indicatie is en er altijd tijdspelingen mogelijk kunnen zijn.Transfer De transfer naar je accommodatie is niet inbegrepen, maar optioneel bij te boeken. Klik hier voor meer informatie en de kosten. Transfertijd Vanaf Banjul luchthaven naar: Bijilo: ca. 20 minuten Kololi: ca. 25 minuten Kotu: ca. 30 minuten Cape Point: ca. 40 minuten Banjul: ca. 40 minuten Je dient er rekening mee te houden dat de hierboven genoemde tijden slechts ter indicatie zijn en er altijd tijdspelingen mogelijk kunnen zijn. Legitimatie Klik hier voor alle informatie over legitimatie, een eventueel visum en formaliteiten op het gebied van gezondheid. Verkeer Het autoverkeer in Gambia is onveilig door onder andere de slechte staat van de wegen en voertuigen. Bij een ongeluk krijgt de chauffeur meestal de schuld. Houd er bovendien rekening mee dat er nergens verkeersborden staan.Openbaar vervoer Reizen met het openbaar vervoer in Gambia is alleen aan te bevelen aan de ervaren reiziger. Er is een busnetwerk en er varen verschillende veerboten waarmee je de Gambia Rivier kunt oversteken.Taxi Men kan drie soorten taxi's vinden in Gambia: De bushtaxi: een busje welke dient als een soort openbaar vervoer en zeer goedkoop is. De groene taxi: deze is bedoeld voor toeristen en mogen je ook in het toeristengebied ophalen. Het is verstandig van tevoren de ritprijs af te spreken. De gele taxi's: bestemd voor privé vervoer voor Gambianen, deze mogen niet in het toeristengebied komenAutohuur Autohuur in Gambia is mogelijk maar wordt afgeraden gezien het chaotische verkeer. Tijdsverschil Het is in Gambia tijdens onze wintermaanden 1 uur vroeger en tijdens onze zomermaanden 2 uur vroeger.Geldzaken De Gambiaanse munt is de Dalasi (D), onderverdeeld in 100 Bututs. Er zijn (beperkt) munten van 1, 5, 10, 25 en 50 Bututs en er is een munt van 1 Dalasi. Bankbiljetten zijn er van 5, 10, 20, 25, 50, 100 en 200 Dalasi. In Gambia vind je op een beperkt aantal plaatsen pinautomaten, die creditcards (alleen Visa en Mastercard) en Maestro-bankpassen (moeten ‘aan’ staan voor buiten Europa) accepteren. Houd er rekening mee dat het aantal automaten beperkt is en buiten bedrijf kunnen zijn, door bijvoorbeeld storingen. Met een bankpas kan alleen geld uit een automaat gepint worden, met een creditcard kan naast het geld pinnen uit een automaat ook betaald worden bij hotels, sommige restaurants en excursies. Het blijft verstandig ook contanten bij je te hebben. Je kunt je euro's ter plaatse omwisselen in de hotels of bij speciaal daarvoor bestemde wisselkantoren die veelvuldig te vinden zijn in het toeristengebied. Let daarbij op de koers. Deze kan per locatie variëren. Je kunt ook je excursies betalen met een creditcard of bankpas. Houd er dan wel rekening mee dat de kosten in de meeste gevallen hoger uitkomen. Ook de bank in Nederland kan nog een vergoeding voor een betaling buiten de eurozone vragen. Je kunt dit voorkomen door contante euro’s mee te nemen. In dit geval dien je wel te bedenken dat het meenemen van grote hoeveelheden contant geld risico’s met zich meebrengt en dat het geld bij verlies of diefstal niet verzekerd is. Zet je pinpas ‘aan’ Voor je veiligheid hebben de meeste banken betaalpassen standaard geblokkeerd voor gebruik buiten Europa. Als je op vakantie gaat buiten Europa kunt je je pinpas kosteloos ‘aan’zetten bij je bank. De bank kan je meer informatie geven. Accommodaties en borg Let op! Het is gebruikelijk in Gambia dat bij aankomst in de accommodatie een borg wordt gevraagd, deze kun je doorgaans met cash of creditcard voldoen. Tijdens je verblijf kun je met deze borg consumpties ‘op rekening’ bestellen. Wel zo handig! Elektriciteit Het voltage in Gambia is 220 Volt, adapters kun je het beste vanuit Nederland meenemen. Het zijn Engelse stekkerdozen dus reisstekkers zijn gewenst.

Holiday Gambia: 'the Smiling Coast of Africa' The ever-bright sun, colorful people, and exotic natural beauty make Gambia a fantastic holiday destination. Gambia is better known as 'the Smiling Coast of Africa'. And for good reason! Discover the tropical beaches, genuine hospitality, and cultural splendor of Africa for yourself and book your Gambia holiday with Corendon now! Affordable Gambia Holidays Although Gambia is the smallest country in Africa, it boasts immense natural beauty. The 70-kilometer coastline with pristine white sandy beaches is a good reason alone to choose a Gambia holiday. Sunbathe on the beach, relax with a cocktail in hand... But Gambia offers much more than sun, sea, and sand. Venture inland and admire the vast mangrove forests, home to more than 450 different bird species. Gambia Holiday Information: Gambia Weather: Gambia is a tropical holiday paradise with warm seawater, swaying palm trees, and over 7 to 8 hours of sunshine per day. From November to May, you can enjoy an average temperature of 21 to 27 degrees Celsius during a Gambia holiday. And the sun shines year-round! It's no wonder Gambia is a popular winter sun destination. View our detailed information about the Gambia climate. Gambia Attractions: Cruising on 'The Gambia' The Gambia's main tourist attraction is the eponymous river, 'The Gambia'. This river is the lifeblood of Gambia and flows the entire length of the country. Taking a boat trip is an absolute must during your Gambia holiday. The water is fringed by lush jungle, where you can spot birds and perhaps even hippos or crocodiles. Bargain at the Banjul Market Want to experience authentic Gambian life? Then do your shopping at the market! Stroll through narrow streets lined with handmade stalls and pick up unique souvenirs. You name it, you'll find it for sale: food, clothing, household appliances... Recommended places to visit during your Gambia holiday include the Albert Market in Banjul and the Serrekunda Market in Serrekunda. Hotels and Apartments in Gambia: Corendon offers a varied selection of apartments and hotels in Gambia. Corendon has carefully selected all accommodations to make your Gambia holiday as pleasant as possible. When selecting accommodations, attention is paid to the location in relation to beaches, restaurants and city centers. Related More holidays in Gambia All holidays Gambia Luxury holiday Gambia All Inclusive Gambia Last minute Gambia Hotels Gambia Gambia with children General information Capital: Banjul Population: 1,883,051 (2013) Area: 11,295 km2 Language: English Religion: 90% Muslim, 9% Christian Time difference: 2 hours earlier in summer, 1 hour earlier in winter Currency: Dalasi Form of government: Republic Electricity: 220V, 50 Hertz AC GDP per capita: $2,000 (2011) Country code: +220 Local emergency numbers: Ambulance 116, police 117, fire department 118 Food and drink In the holiday areas, most restaurants are completely geared towards tourists. You can choose from all kinds of restaurants, from Chinese to Mexican. In the cities, you can eat African food very cheaply, but be careful and pay close attention to hygiene! People in Gambia eat a lot of rice, chicken, and fish, usually cooked on a fire. The tap water in Gambia is of reasonably good quality in many hotels, but drinking it is not recommended. Therefore, we recommend buying bottled mineral water. One of the few factories in Gambia is the Banyul Brewery, where the highly drinkable Gambian beer Julbrew (green bottles) is brewed. Language: English is the official language in Gambia, particularly in government, education, the legal system, and, of course, in tourist centers. More than half of Gambians speak a native language in addition to English. Nature: Gambia is a paradise for bird watchers. Approximately 450 different species have been counted so far, and new ones are still being discovered. Unfortunately, almost all large mammals are extinct due to hunting in the 19th century. You won't find the famous "African Big Five" in Gambia, as elephants, rhinoceroses, giraffes, lions, buffalo, and large antelope have sought refuge elsewhere. Deep inland, hippos and crocodiles still live in the Gambia River. Various small monkey species, such as the velvet monkey and the patas monkey, are found everywhere. Chimpanzees only live in Baboon Island National Park. There are also small antelope species, aardvarks, and warthogs. The Gambia has a number of national parks and reserves where these animals can be admired. Holidays January 1: New Year February 14: Independence Day February 27: Ascension Day of Muhammad (Isra and Mi'raj) February 28 – March 30: Ramadan March 8: International Women's Day March 30: Eid al-Fitr June 6: Eid al-Adha September 5: Birthday of Muhammad (Milad un-Nabi) December 25 & 26: Christmas December 31: New Year's Eve Background / History The earliest written reference to The Gambia is recorded in the account of Hanno the Carthaginian. The Carthaginians lived in ancient Europe/Mediterranean around 470 BC and made many intercontinental voyages, thus coming into contact with distant civilizations. The first Portuguese contact with The Gambia was in 1456 when a Portuguese exploratory fleet landed on what is now James Island. They established trading posts where they traded salt, iron, gunpowder, and rifles in exchange for ivory, gold, ebony, and slaves. In the early 17th century, the Portuguese colonies in Brazil faced a labor shortage, leading to this shortage being met from West Africa with slaves. The Dutch and the French followed suit, causing Portugal to lose its monopoly. The slaves were put to work in countries including the Americas, Jamaica, Suriname, and the Antilles. In 1661, the British took permanent possession of James Island, marking the beginning of British rule over Gambia. The French took possession of what is now Senegal. Slavery was abolished under British rule only in 1807, but the British continued to occupy Gambia. After the Second World War, there were growing calls for self-determination, but Gambia did not gain political independence from Great Britain until February 18, 1965. On April 24, 1970, Gambia became an independent republic. A more sustainable holiday. Truly sustainable air travel doesn't exist yet. But if you want to reduce your footprint (a little), you can buy Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) when booking your air travel. You can read more about this here. By buying SAF, you contribute to lower CO2 emissions from your flight. You can also choose certified accommodation. These hotels meet the highest sustainability standards and are therefore a better choice for your holiday. Are you using a transfer to your hotel? On average, a bus carries more people than a taxi, reducing CO2 emissions per passenger. A bus transfer is therefore often a more sustainable choice than a private transfer. The Gambia is located on the west coast of Africa and is completely landlocked by Senegal. The Gambia's natural environment is characterized by the Gambia River, which flows through the country. Along the river and the sea, you'll find mangroves and an abundance of bird and fish species. The mangroves are important because they form natural barriers against soil erosion. It's important to realize that Gambia is a country facing significant challenges when it comes to environmental conservation, poverty, and equal rights. If you visit Gambia, you'll see a lot of trash along the road and people living in dilapidated houses or on the streets. It can therefore be a bit of a shift when you step off the plane. But most Gambians will welcome you with open arms. Most people in Gambia are Muslim. Women are often veiled. It's respectful to wear covering clothing yourself, especially when venturing out of tourist areas. Music and dance play a central role in Gambian life, and local festivals and celebrations are often filled with traditional music and colorful dance performances. Don't hesitate to join in the dancing yourself; Gambians are friendly and happy to welcome you. Be mindful when exploring Gambia. While you can enjoy numerous adventurous excursions and activities at our destinations, it's important to be aware of their potential impact on nature and culture. In general, as long as you treat people, animals, and nature with respect, you can enjoy your holiday with peace of mind. Click here for an overview of useful do's and don'ts during excursions. The Gambian mangroves are best admired from a kayak. There are several nature reserves you can visit in Gambia or neighboring Senegal. A batik workshop is also recommended: here you can learn how typical African fabrics are printed. If you want to learn more about the country's history, you can visit James Island and Fort James. The interior of Gambia offers a different perspective on the country. Talk to a local taxi driver to take you there and show you the most beautiful spots. Social Impact: There are several ways to help or support the local population or the environment at your holiday destination. Ask your local tour guide for their tips on charities or social initiatives. Every destination has its own challenges related to climate or social issues. Corendon supports the Bakau Basketball Academy (BBA) in Gambia: a place where young people can play sports together every day of the week under the guidance of two former professional basketball players. Many children in the disadvantaged neighborhoods of Banjul lack role models in their immediate surroundings. Thanks to the BBA, they have the necessary distraction and perspective. Dutchman Ed Spier has already traveled to Gambia four times at our expense to help the BBA grow. Flight duration: The flight to Banjul airport takes approximately 6 hours and 15 minutes. Check the flight time to Gambia. Please note that the flight time mentioned above is for guidance only and may vary. Transfer: Transfer to your accommodation is not included but can be booked as an option. Click here for more information and the costs. Transfer time From Banjul Airport to: Bijilo: approx. 20 minutes Kololi: approx. 25 minutes Kotu: approx. 30 minutes Cape Point: approx. 40 minutes Banjul: approx. 40 minutes Please note that the times mentioned above are for guidance only and are subject to change. Identification Click here for all information about identification, possible visas, and health formalities. Traffic Driving in Gambia is unsafe due to, among other things, the poor condition of the roads and vehicles. In the event of an accident, the driver is usually to blame. Also, keep in mind that there are no road signs anywhere. Public Transport Traveling by public transport in Gambia is only recommended for experienced travelers. There is a bus network and several ferries that allow you to cross the Gambia River. Taxis There are three types of taxis in Gambia: Bush taxis: a minibus that serves as a form of public transport and is very inexpensive. Green taxis: these are intended for tourists and may also pick you up in tourist areas. It's wise to agree on a fare in advance. Yellow taxis: intended for private transportation for Gambians; these are not allowed in tourist areas. Car rental: Car rental in Gambia is possible but not recommended due to the chaotic traffic. Time difference: Gambia is one hour earlier during our winter months and two hours earlier during our summer months. Money matters: The Gambian currency is the Dalasi (D), divided into 100 Bututs. There are (limited) coins of 1, 5, 10, 25, and 50 Bututs, and a 1 Dalasi coin. Banknotes are available in denominations of 5, 10, 20, 25, 50, 100, and 200 Dalasi. ATMs are available in a limited number of places in Gambia, which accept credit cards (Visa and Mastercard only) and Maestro debit cards (must be activated for travel outside Europe). Please note that the number of ATMs is limited and may be out of service, for example, due to malfunctions. A debit card can only be used to withdraw money from ATMs; a credit card can be used to pay for hotels, some restaurants, and excursions, in addition to withdrawing money from ATMs. It's always wise to carry cash. You can exchange your euros locally at hotels or at designated exchange offices, which are frequently found in tourist areas. Pay attention to the exchange rate, as this can vary by location. You can also pay for excursions with a credit or debit card. However, keep in mind that the costs will usually be higher. Banks in the Netherlands may also charge a fee for payments outside the eurozone. You can avoid this by carrying cash in euros. In this case, keep in mind that carrying large amounts of cash carries risks and that the money is not insured against loss or theft. Enable your debit card. For your security, most banks have blocked debit cards for use outside Europe by default. If you're going on holiday outside Europe, you can activate your debit card free of charge at your bank. Your bank can provide you with more information. Accommodation and deposits Please note! It's customary in Gambia to ask for a deposit upon arrival at your accommodation; you can usually pay this with cash or credit card. During your stay, you can use this deposit to order refreshments on account. Very convenient! Electricity: The voltage in Gambia is 220 volts. It's best to bring adapters from the Netherlands. They are UK-style sockets, so travel plugs are required.

website_content.original_text: Search HolidaysRecommended HotelsExperiencesAll DestinationsFind Out MorePopular Holidays Holidays to The Gambia have exotic wildlife, palm-packed beaches and haggle-friendly markets in the bag. Bite-sized AfricaSqueezed onto Africa’s west coast, The Gambia’s basically taken a chunk out of Senegal’s shoreline. Savannahs and sandy beaches, baboons and buffalos, markets and mangroves – it packs a culture-blazing itinerary. Plus, its small size is actually a perk – it means you can cram more sights into one break. Not only that, but it’s only six hours away and in the same time zone as the UK, and the official language is English, so you get winter sun without the stress. Chimps and crocsThe Gambia goes wild with wallowing hippos, chimps swinging along the Gambia River and Nile crocodiles at the Kiang West National Park. Africa's known for its safaris, and this spot doesn’t disappoint, either. Tonnes of nature reserves and national parks let you inside these animals’ natural habitats, at a respectful distance, of course. Look up, too. The Abuko Nature Reserve alone is home to more than 300 species of exotic bird to suit you twitchers. Beach lifeWhen you’re not wildlife-watching, you can be sunbathing on strips of sand. Kotu and Kololi are both top resorts – Kololi is backed by a big strip of bars and foodie places, as well. But the wildlife is never far away. In Bakau, Cape Point beach rolls down to the bird-squawking wetlands of Cape Creek. And on the other side of the river, Jinack Island’s 11-kilometre stretch of au naturel shoreline will have you dreaming up your desert island discs selection. Post-sunset shenanigansDaytimes in The Gambia are at the chilled end of the scale – wildlife-watching and sunbathing will probably take up a big chunk of space on your itinerary. Come nighttime, though, there’s no shortage of bars, clubs and restaurants to get your teeth into. Kololi’s the country’s nightlife hub. Here, the famous Senegambia Strip buzzes with energy after dark – once a row of roadside shacks, it’s now the go-to spot for eating out, mingling with the locals and late-night clubbing. Off-beat adventuresLike a lot of developing countries, The Gambia comes with a few unique charms – but they’re all part of the authentic experience. The roads are on the bumpy side, Wi-Fi isn’t always as reliable as what you’re used to at home, and not all hotel lobbies and restaurants have air con. You’ll probably notice the odd power cut during your stay, too. However, all of this makes for an adventure to remember – and the smiling locals, tropical shores and off-the-beaten-track experiences you’ll get here will more than make up for the lack of mod-cons. marketing_content.original_text: Gambia & Senegal Wildlife Tour Your Itinerary Your adventure starts here! Day 1 - Arrive in The Gambia Day 2 - Explore Makasutu forest and waterways Day 3 - Sunset cruise Day 4 - Go wild in Senegal Day 5 - Discover Senegal Day 6 - Back to The Gambia Day 7 - Birdwatching

website_content.original_text: Gambia Senegal Wildlife Tour | Fleewinter Destination Request a quote Notice: JavaScript is required for this content. × Search Gambia & Senegal Wildlife Tour 8 days from £2,320 per person The Gambia & Senegal Wildlife Tour makes a fabulous introduction to the wildlife of Africa and, for bird lovers, it’s an absolute must. See monkeys, giraffes, zebra and more, not to mention some of the 540-plus species of birds found here. This exciting itinerary combines three unique places to stay, a floating river lodge deep in the heart of Makasutu Forest, a small boutique hotel by the beach and glamping in a Senegalese wildlife reserve. We recommend a minimum of 8 days, but longer itineraries are also available. Suitable for couples and families with children 16 years and older. Itineraries for families with younger children are also available. Your Itinerary Day 1 - Arrive in The Gambia Arrive in the afternoon at the Banjul Airport where your driver will meet you for your transfer (45 minutes) to the stunning Mandina Lodges in the heart of Makasutu Forest. Here you’ll find your floating lodge on a tributary of the River Gambia. That evening, dine alfresco under a thatched cabana beneath a star-studded African sky. Accommodation Day 2 - Explore Makasutu forest and waterways Having enjoyed a coffee or tea on your verandah watching the forest awake, head out for a walk with your guide and learn more about the flora and fauna of the area including the large troop of baboons that live here. Once back at the lodges, take a leisurely late breakfast and spend the rest of the day relaxing by the river or the pool, watching the birds that regularly visit. In the late afternoon, your guide will take you out in a canoe to explore the mangroves and waterways. As well as the varied birdlife, you’ll see local fishermen and, at low tide, women collecting oysters from the exposed mangrove roots. Accommodation Day 3 - Sunset cruise On your second morning, head out with your guide along the river by canoe or on another forest walk, perhaps visiting the Gambia Horse and Donkey Trust. Chat to one of their volunteers for a fascinating insight into the work of this charity. In the late afternoon, join other guests at Mandina for a cruise along the river in a motorboat to see flocks of birds coming home to roost as the sun sets behind the mangroves while enjoying a bottle of South African house wine (one bottle per couple). Accommodation Day 4 - Go wild in Senegal Start the day early with a private transfer to Banjul’s ferry port from where you’ll cross the River Gambia. This is an adventure in itself with a colourful collection of vehicles, people, and often animals streaming onto the ferry. Your guide will look after you all the way. From here it’s just a short drive across the border to Senegal and Fathala Wildlife Reserve. Staying in luxury safari tents, with air-conditioning and an ensuite bathroom, you’ll soon settle in. That afternoon set off on a sunset game drive through the African bush for the chance to see the rare West African giant derby eland as well as zebra, giraffes, rhino, buffalo, warthogs, several species of monkeys and numerous bird species. Accommodation Day 5 - Discover Senegal Visit a traditional Senegalese market and bakery and learn about local life. Meet local artisans, see traditional crafts and fabrics, taste baobab juice and be back at Fathala in time for lunch. In the late afternoon, join a guided walk through the Africa bush to learn about the plants and smaller animals that live on the reserve. This is an excellent opportunity for bird photography. There’s no guarantee what you may see, but frequently sighted bird species include the Abyssinian roller, the rose-ringed parakeet, the western red-billed hornbill, the long-tailed glossy starling and many more. Accommodation Day 6 - Back to The Gambia It’s time to return to The Gambia and transfer to Leo’s Beach Resort set in an elevated position overlooking a quiet sandy beach. The rest of your day is free to spend relaxing by the pool or the beach. Alternatively, the nearby village of Tanji is a short taxi ride away. Here you can see the local fishing boats known as pirogues being unloaded and watch the hustle and bustle of the fish market. It’s a mesmerising, colourful sight set against a cacophony as gulls squawk overhead, and people haggle over the price of fish. Accommodation Day 7 - Birdwatching Rise early to make the most of your time with your birding expert. If there’s a particular habitat or species you’re interested in, let us know; otherwise, leave it to your guide to take you to the best birdwatching location on any specific day. Likely sites include Abuko Nature Reserve, home to approximately 250 species of birds, including giant kingfishers and turaco; Brufut Forest for its array of woodland birds, or nearby Tanji Bird Reserve, not far from your hotel. Accommodation Day 8 - Bid farewell to the Smiling Coast of West Africa After a leisurely breakfast, with plenty of time for a walk along the beach or a last swim in the pool, leave Leo’s Beach Resort around mid-morning to check-in for your flight home. Details - This Gambia & Senegal Wildlife Tour itinerary costs from £2,320 per person based on 2 sharing. What's included? website_content.original_text: Gambia Gambia Holidays Gambia…The Smiling Coast of Africa! Holidays in The Gambia Gambia is a small West African country bordered by Senegal on three sides with a narrow Atlantic coastline and is known as ‘The Smiling Coast of Africa’ thanks to the warm and friendly welcome you’ll receive from the locals. Gambia is perfect for laid-back beach holidays on endless, uncrowded swathes of golden sands alongside the 50-mile-long shoreline. You’ll also get to experience the country’s rich and diverse history, amazing natural beauty, thrilling activities, eclectic wildlife, and authentic cuisine. And, what’s more, Gambia is only just over six hours flying time from the UK and is on the same time-zone, so no jet-lag! When is the best time to visit Gambia? Gambia offers a sub-tropical climate with between six to 12 hours of daily sunshine throughout the year and average monthly temperatures between 24oC and 27oC. The country also has two distinct seasons – the dry season from November to May and the wet season from June to October. Where is the best place to stay in Gambia? Discover an array of places to stay in Gambia to suit every budget. Beach-lovers flock to the main resorts of the long-established Kololi and the vibrant and newly developed Kotu, while nature lovers can check into floating lodges on the River Gambia. Whether you’re seeking bed and breakfast, self-catering, half-board, or all-inclusive; Hays Travel will find you the best accommodation for your Gambia holiday. Travel guide The Gambia is popular with all ages and tastes including families, couples, friends, and single travellers. From sun-worshippers and activity fans to avid explorers and culture enthusiasts, holidays to Gambia have something for everyone. Best time to visit: November-May Average flight time: 6 Hours 20 Minutes Most suited for: Couples Currency: Gambian Dalasi Time Difference: -1 Hour BEACH LIFE AND CITIES Spend a relaxing morning or afternoon enjoying the African sunshine and swimming in the azure ocean that laps the golden stretches of sands in the vibrant resorts of Kololi and Katu. If you’re seeking splendid isolation, escape to the less-crowded and secluded beaches at Cape Point and Brufut. City-wise you can head to the capital Banjul on St Mary’s Island, where Gambia meets the Atlantic Ocean – here you can admire the colonial buildings like the Gambia National Museum, shop for local handicrafts at lively Albert Market, and admire the architectural marvel of Arch 22, the gateway to the city. THINGS TO SEE AND DO! Tee off in the sunshine on the fairways of Koloki Golf Course and Fajara Golf Club. With over 600 species of birds indigenous to Gambia, it’s a birdwatcher’s delight, so don’t forget your binoculars. Follow the walking trails through Abuko Nature Reserve to spot Vervet, Western Red Colobus, and Patas Monkeys. Get up close to the 100 crocodiles who live in Katchikally Crocodile Pool and take a relaxing cruise past birds, wildlife, and mangroves on the Gambia River. Head to Bakau to pick up woodcarvings at the craft market or see how fabrics are made on a visit to Serekunda Batik Factory. Delve into the nation’s rich and vivid history at the iconic Kunta Kinteh Island, Wassu Stone Circles, and Fort Bullen. Food & Drink Prepare to embark on a culinary journey that celebrates the rich cultural heritage of The Gambia. From traditional Gambian dishes to international cuisines like Italian, Chinese, Indian, and Lebanese; the dining scene is a fusion of flavours that will delight your palate. Typical dishes you’ll see on local menus include Akara (black-eyed pea fritters), Benachin (one pot stew with fish or chicken), Domoada (peanut-based dish), freshly-baked Talapa bread, and Yassa (chillies, limes, onions, mustard, and stock) with beef, fish, prawns, or vegetables. Non-alcoholic drinks to sample include Baobab Juice and Wonjo Juice and also the mildly-alcoholic Palm Wine. website_content.original_text: Gambia Holidays 2025/2026We’ll say it up front – Gambia isn’t your average holiday destination. With gold sand beaches, an incredible wealth of wildlife, energetic craft markets and some of the friendliest locals you’re bound to meet on your travels, this little African country is in a holiday genre of its own. TRAVEL AWARE – STAYING SAFE AND HEALTHY ABROAD (foreign office travel advice)Gambia Holiday Deals 2025/2026 View more dealsThe smiling coast of AfricaGambia is a slim country along the western coast of mainland Africa, hugged almost completely by Senegal, minus its narrow coastline. It’s the smallest country in all of Africa, named after the river snaking through the land. Gambia first entered the sights of tourists after a group of Scandinavian holidaymakers catapulted it onto the scene in the sixties, but the country itself did the rest. Holidays to Gambia combine swathes of beaches with exotic wildlife, and locals so welcoming that the country has earned itself the nickname ‘the smiling coast of Africa’. Key Facts for Gambia: Currency: Gambian Dalasi (GMD) Language: English Timezone: GMT +0 Avg. Flight Time: 5 hours 30 minutes (from London) Visas: You do not need a visa if you’re travelling to Gambia for up to 28 days. RegionsBijiloCape PointKololiKotu BeachFurther ReadingArticlesBest HotelsFood And Drink Location Where is Gambia? Where's best to stay in Gambia?From lively beach resorts to peaceful coastal escapes, Gambia’s top regions each offer something unique, whether you’re after wildlife, nightlife or sun-soaked relaxation. Beaches in GambiaGambia’s coastline offers sun-soaked escapes with a mix of lively beaches and tranquil stretches. Bijilo Beach is a peaceful spot with soft sands and gentle waves, perfect for families or couples. Nearby cafes and small restaurants serve traditional local dishes, and you might even spot monkeys from Bijilo Forest Park nearby. Cape Point features golden sands and calm Atlantic waters, ideal for swimming, splashing around with the kids or a quiet stroll. Its rocky backdrop and scenic views make it a photographer’s dream. Kololi Beach is a lively and bustling option, lined with sunbeds and a promenade full of bars, restaurants and shops. It’s the heart of Gambia’s beach life, perfect for those seeking a social vibe with plenty of amenities on hand. Kotu Beach stretches for miles, offering a quieter, natural escape. You can explore tidal pools, spot birdlife in the mangroves, or simply relax on the soft sand with the gentle surf. It’s perfect for nature lovers or those looking for their own tranquil spot. Wildlife in GambiaGambia has some of the best wildlife reserves and forests in West Africa, making it a fantastic destination for nature lovers and animal enthusiasts alike. Just south of Cape Point in the town of Bakau is the Kachikally Crocodile Pool, a sacred site where crocodiles glide through the water. Traditionally used for fertility rituals, it’s also a fascinating place to see these ancient reptiles up close. The Bijilo Forest Park, also called Monkey Park, is a protected area home to playful monkeys, diverse birdlife, and shaded walking trails – perfect for a peaceful nature stroll. A short drive south of Banjul takes you to the Abuko Nature Reserve, Gambia’s first official wildlife reserve. Here you’ll encounter monkeys, reptiles like crocodiles and cobras, and more than 200 bird species, making it a birdwatcher’s paradise. For those seeking a true African adventure, head on a safari excursion from Kololi or Banjul, along the Gambia River or into the bush. Spot hippos, giraffes, lions, and other iconic wildlife in their natural habitat, making for an unforgettable experience. Craft markets in GmbiaLocal craft markets are the heart of any Gambian city. Here, locals display their wares, fresh fruits and vegetables pile high, and you’ll see the iconic visual of women balancing wicker baskets atop their heads. Cape Point Markets are small but charming. At the Bakau Craft Market, you’ll find stalls selling handmade jewelry, textiles, and souvenirs, perfect for picking up unique keepsakes while experiencing local life. The markets in Kotu Beach offer a mix of beachfront shopping and local culture. The Kotu Craft Village is a standout, with colorful fabrics, handmade crafts, and tropical fruits, giving visitors a taste of authentic Gambian crafts. Senegambia Craft Market in Kololi has a lively community vibe. Stalls are packed with traditional carvings, paintings, and woven goods, while street performers and local musicians add to the energetic atmosphere, giving a true taste of Gambian culture. Albert Market in Banjul is the country’s largest and most famous market. It’s a bustling hub of activity, where you can haggle for leather goods, wooden carvings, spices, and local delicacies. Places to go in GambiaGambia may be small, but it’s packed with attractions that will give you a taste of the local culture, nature and beach charm. In Kololi, Bijilo Forest Park is a huge (51 hectare!) coastal reserve renowned for its rich biodiversity. Stroll through the trails that wind through the dense forest and catch glimpses of vervet monkeys, red colobus monkeys, and over 130 bird species. It’s a tranquil escape for nature enthusiasts and families seeking a blend of wildlife and coastal beauty. The Senegambia Strip is the heart of Kololi’s vibrant tourist scene. This bustling area is lined with a variety of shops, restaurants, bars, and nightclubs, offering a lively atmosphere, whether you’re after an evening stroll, some local cuisine, or the energetic nightlife. If you love natural charm and local culture, head to Kotu Beach for leisurely walks and birdwatching. Browse the markets, sunbathe on the soft sand or try your hand at beach volleyball and soak up the serene surroundings. Things to see in GambiaFrom historic landmarks to hidden gems, Gambia offers a range of sights that capture its culture, history, and natural beauty. Arch 22 is an iconic arch that commemorates the 1994 coup and offers panoramic views over Banjul and the Gambia River. It stands 36 metres high so climb to the top for the incredible photo-worthy views and with a cafe and museum here too, you can appreciate Gambian history with a nice treat. The Bakau Botanical Gardens offers a peaceful oasis perfect for a romantic stroll. The gardens are brimming with tropical plants, palm trees, and serene pathways giving you an escape from the bustling towns. It’s ideal for families or nature lovers, or if you’re looking for an afternoon out of the beaming sun. To explore more of Gambia, head to Tanji, particularly the Tanji Village Museum. It’s a small but fascinating museum showing Gambian fishing culture and history, with traditional boats, tools and exhibits on local life. Nightlife in GambiaGambia’s nightlife is lively but relaxed – the ultimate combo. With options ranging from beach bars and live music venues to bustling clubs and local cultural evenings, you can expect a bit of everything. Nightlife in Bijilo is low-key, with a handful of beach bars and small restaurants offering live music and cocktails. It’s the perfect place for couples or friends looking for a relaxed evening with ocean views. Cape Point is also a quieter, scenic area with intimate nightlife. Expect sunset dinners followed by a few drinks and a peaceful atmosphere. Kololi is the heart of Gambia’s party scene. The Senegambia Strip comes alive at night with bars, nightclubs, and live entertainment, ideal for younger party crowds or anyone seeking energetic nightlife, cocktails and music until late. Kotu Beach offers a good mix of casual beach bars and lively venues, with live music and friendly atmospheres. It’s a great pick for families and friends wanting a lively night out without the bustle of Kololi. Gambian cuisineGambian cuisine is a hearty and flavourful mix of West African, Portuguese, and French influences, shaped by the country’s rivers, fertile land and coastal access. Expect a huge focus on dishes with rice, seafood, plantain and aromas of garlic, onions and tomato. Domoda is a rich peanut butter stew made with meat, fish, or chicken and vegetables, usually served with rice. Considered as Gambia’s national dish, it’s a must try for anyone wanting an authentic taste of local flavours. Street food in Gambia is popular for affordable lunches and snacks, like fish rolls – fried fish in soft bread – fataya – deep-fried pastry pockets filled with spiced meat or fish – and even kebabs, with grilled beef, chicken or seafood. Desserts in Gambia are often simple and sweet with a focus on local ingredients like peanuts and tropical fruits including mango, papaya and pineapple. You can expect to find sweet treats in my food stalls and local cafes, perfect for an afternoon snack or after your evening meal. Drinks in GambiaGambia has a variety of traditional drinks that reflect its culture, climate and local ingredients, perfect for refreshing yourself while basking in the beaming sunshine. Baobab Juice is a tangy, vitamin-rich drink made from baobab fruit pulp and often served chilled. It pairs well with grilled fish, fried snacks or light meals for a refreshing balance. The perfect accompaniment for your spicy evening meal, Bissap is a sweetened hibiscus flower drink – sometimes flavored with mint or ginger, it perfectly compliments the bold flavours of your meal. Attaya is a Gambian Tea – a strong green tea brewed with sugar and traditionally enjoyed with biscuits, cakes or peanut-based sweets. Perfecting attaya is a long process involving pouring the tea from a height, several times and between cups, to create three different strength teapots. Palm Wine is a mildly alcoholic, lightly sweet drink tapped from palm trees and it’s a great compliment to any seafood or meat dish. Costs in GambiaPrices in Gambia can vary depending on where you are, but here are some typical average costs: A three-course meal for two at a mid-range restaurant can cost around £35–£55. Food from street vendors is much cheaper, usually less than a few pounds. A bottle of local beer might cost around £1.40, a soft drink about £1.10, a glass of wine £4–£5, and cocktails in the more upscale bars £6–£8. A short taxi ride of about 5 km during the day would typically cost around £4.50. How much could some typical excursions in Gambia cost me? Head on a half day tour around Gambia’s capital, Banjul, exploring the sights and history for around £50 per adult and £20 per child. Enjoy an evening preparing and eating an evening meal with a local family in their home, for around £30 per person. Frequently asked questions about holidays to GambiaWhat is the best time to go to Gambia?Make the most of the country’s amazing, stunning beaches during the dry season and enjoy average temperatures of around 24 degrees celsius across the coastal areas. Whatever time of the year you choose for your holiday to Gambia, you can rest easy knowing that you will experience tropical temperatures with sunshine all around you. Is Gambia expensive?Look to book an all inclusive holiday Gambia and everything will be included in your price from drinks and food to flights, hotels and transfers. Local supermarkets offer you the chance to pick up little bits such as snacks and any essentials you may have forgotten, all at relatively cheap prices too. Does Gambia have beaches?It certainly does and they’re often quiet, serene places where you can unwind and relax in the sunshine. Along the coastal areas you’ll find beautiful sandy beaches that are just waiting for you to explore them. With an amazing climate, friendly locals and so much wildlife on offer throughout the country, you can either choose to relax by the sea or explore inland some more. Why is Gambia popular with tourists?As there is so much to do in The Gambia, there is never a dull moment. There’s so many activities to dive into as well as the beautiful surroundings you will find yourself in. Many tourists love the diverse wildlife on offer and with the opportunity to see this first hand you can rest assured your holiday is going to be memorable. What are the hottest months in Gambia?Around May time are the hottest parts of the year when it comes to a holiday to The Gambia. As you head out of the dry season and into the wet season you can experience higher temperatures such as in August but you run the risk of rain, although it can be quite refreshing during soaring temperatures! What is the currency in Gambia?The currency in Gambia is the Gambian Dalasi (GMD). This is a closed currency which means you can only buy and sell your travel money once you’re in the country, and before you leave again. What language do they speak in Gambia?The most common spoken language in Gambia is English, although you are likely to hear many tribal languages, like Mandinka and Wolof. What is the time difference between the UK and Gambia?Gambia shares the same timezone as the UK, GMT +0, so there is no time difference. How long is the flight from the UK to Gambia?The average flight time from the UK (London) to Gambia is 5 hours 30 minutes. This can vary depending on where you’re flying from. Do I need a visa to travel to Gambia?For holidays up to 28 days in Gambia you do not need a visa. For holidays longer than 28 days,you can get an extension – find out more information.

website_content.original_text: The Gambia tours & holidaysThe smallest country in continental Africa leaves a big, big impressionAlthough petite in size, The Gambia is a powerhouse of biodiversity. With an abundance of different ecosystems and nature reserves, you don't have to travel far to see some amazing wildlife. Although this part of West Africa is a birdwatchers' paradise with over 600 species of birds, you'll also want to be on the lookout for Nile crocodiles, hippos, spitting cobras and monkeys. Your camera is a non-negotiable for a trip to the Gambia.Our The Gambia trips Refine search Senegal & The Gambia Adventure 12 days Original From GBP £2,376Build your dream adventure Let's create an exclusive trip for your group. Explore tailor-made trips Get inspired on The Good Times Read all stories Guides5 West African countries that should be on your radarThe Goods 2025: New trips & experiences7 new ways to make a difference as you travel with Intrepid The Goods 2025: New trips & experiences12 new ways to get closer to nature with Intrepid The Goods 2025: New trips & experiences8 of the best traditional foods to try in West Africa The Goods 2025: New trips & experiences9 new experiences for beach lovers and island hoppers Read all stories We also travel toTogoSenegalBeninGhanaThe Gambia at a glance CAPITAL CITYBanjul (population 480,000)POPULATION2.7 millionCURRENCYGMDLANGUAGEEnglish (official), Wolof, Mandinka, FulaTIME ZONE(GMT) CasablancaCALLING CODE+220ELECTRICITYType G (Irish/British 3-pin) Type C (European 2-pin) Learn more about The GambiaBest time to visit The GambiaBest time to visit The GambiaThe best time to visit Gambia is from November to February when temperatures are pleasant, and there’s little humidity. Conveniently, this is also the best time to spot birds and wildlife as the country is green and lush.The average temperature rises between mid-February and April, and humidity can be oppressive. Intense periods of rain have been known to wash away some of the roads.Geography and environmentGeography and environmentCompletely surrounded by Senegal save for its 80-kilometre stretch of coastline, the Gambia is an exceptionally flat country. The highest point is only 53 metres above sea level. The country’s namesake river begins in the east and travels among tropical rainforests before gradually giving way to mangrove swamps and coastlines. Further from the river, savannahs and plantation woodlands dot the landscape.Top 5 Gambian drinksTop 5 Gambian drinks1. BissapBlood-red and extremely sweet, bissap (or manjo) is an infused herbal tea made from the flowers of the hibiscus plant, and it’s the nation’s number one drink. Typically flavoured with ginger or mint, it makes for a refreshing midday beverage. And with preliminary studies recently suggesting that it may reduce blood pressure, you may well return home in better shape than you left.2. AtaayaAs much a social rite as a no-holds-barred caffeine injection, try the three-glass Ataaya ceremony when you’re looking to recharge the batteries or make some local friends. One part Chinese green tea leaves to two parts sugar, three parts water and a bunch of mint – think of it as the teetotaller’s mojito.3. KinkelibaBrewed from the leaves of the local Kinkeliba plant, this strong, sweet herbal tea is mostly drunk as a breakfast tonic or at dusk during Ramadan when its appetite-stimulant qualities assist in gorging on the evening meal.4. BouyiA thick, syrupy juice made from the fruit of the baobab, this ultra-sweet libation imparts an unmatched sugar high and is certainly more appetising than its ungainly tree would have you expect.5. JulBrewDescribed by some beer buffs as evoking aromas of hay, boiled vegetables, canned corn and cardboard, Gambia’s national beer is probably unlikely to scoop any international beer awards. But knocked back on a white sandy beach while being buffed by delightful sea breezes, you’re hardly likely to care.The Gambia travel FAQsDo I need a visa to travel to The Gambia?Most nationalities will need to obtain a visa in advance to travel to The Gambia.Visas are the responsibility of the individual traveller. Entry requirements can change at any time, so it's important that you check for the latest information.You can check the entry requirements for your nationality on your government's foreign travel advisories, consular websites or on our visa and entry requirements page.Do I need to purchase travel insurance before travelling?Absolutely. All passengers travelling with Intrepid are required to purchase travel insurance before the start of their trip. It's important to understand that each country you visit may have its own specific entry requirements, and some destinations mandate travel health insurance for all foreign travellers, regardless of their nationality.Your leader will record your travel insurance details on the first day of the trip. Due to the varying nature, availability and cost of health care around the world, travel insurance is an essential part of every journey.Read more about travel insuranceIs tipping customary in The Gambia?A 10% service charge is usually added to the bill in established restaurants, bars, hotels and taxis — but feel free to tip more than this for exceptional service. At restaurants where a service charge isn’t included, 10% is the acceptable gratuity. Although tipping at other places isn't mandatory it will be much appreciated given the low wages that Gambian service workers are typically paid. Setting aside a small amount for porters, guides and drivers is also a good idea.Can I drink the water in The Gambia?Tap water isn't safe to drink in The Gambia. Hotels and lodges will often provide filtered water, and your local leader is always available to help. Water filtration tablets are often helpful for peace of mind.What is the internet access like in The Gambia?The internet connection can be a little slow in some remote areas, especially in towns further inland. Hotels, cafes and bars in Banjul usually have wi-fi with reliable connectivity.Can I use my mobile phone while in The Gambia?Mobile phone coverage is good in The Gambia’s large cities and towns but less so in rural areas. If you plan to use your mobile phone, ensure you have global roaming activated or download an eSIM before leaving home.What is ATM access like in The Gambia?ATMs can be found at banks in urban areas like Banjul and Serrekunda, though they aren’t always reliable. Due to credit card and bank fraud, caution is advised when using these, and some ATMs may only allow withdrawals of fairly small amounts.Are credit cards accepted in The Gambia?The Gambia is primarily a cash-based economy. Credit cards are generally only accepted at top-end hotels and at some high-end restaurants in Banjul. We recommend you carry enough local currency on your trip.What are the toilets like in The Gambia?Fairly clean western-style toilets can generally be found in Banjul and the towns on the Atlantic Coast. In towns and villages further inland, squat/pit toilets are the norm. Carry your own supply of soap and toilet paper, as this is rarely provided.How do I stay safe and healthy while travelling?We take the health and safety of our travellers seriously and take every measure to ensure that trips are safe, fun and inclusive for everyone. When you travel with us, you have access to our global support network and local on‑ground leadership, and you can rest easy knowing we have a zero-tolerance policy on discrimination.We recommend that all travellers check with their government or national travel advisory organisation for the latest information before departure. The World Health Organisation also provides useful health information.Travelling from Australia?Go to: Smart TravellerFrom Canada?Go to: Canada Travel InformationFrom the UK?Go to: UK Foreign Travel AdviceFrom New Zealand?Go to: Safe TravelFrom the US?Go to: US Department of StateLearn more about safe travels with IntrepidSMALL GROUP TRAVEL THAT'S GOOD ALL OVERWe're here to do good by creating positive change through the joy of travel.We're here to do good by creating positive change through the joy of travel.Our purposeOur purpose
