website_content.translated_text: Select travel date 28.10.25 - 17.11.25 (21 days) Senegal and Gambia On a discovery tour in Senegambia 21 days € 3,299 * * date-specific price Participants: min. 6 - max. 16 Book trip Download travel description Personal advice 02203 9255700 Mon.-Fri. 9:30 a.m. - 5:30 p.m. E-mail Senegal and Gambia On a discovery tour in Senegambia Highlights of the round trip Visit to the UNESCO World Heritage Island of Gorée Tour of the colonial old town of Saint Louis by horse-drawn carriage Boat trips in the Djoudj National Park, the Gambia River Delta and the Sine-Saloum Delta Experience the tropical green Casamance culture: masked dance of the Diola in Coubalan Beautiful beaches at Cap Skirring Experience the whole adventure of West Africa! On this two-country tour, you'll experience extraordinary landscapes from north to south. We'll repeatedly encounter warm-hearted people and their cultures; we'll experience the vibrant culture of the Diola people up close during the masked dance in Coubalan and visit their villages in the beautiful Casamance region in southern Senegal. We'll sail through the bird-rich Djoudj National Park in a pirogue and experience the mangrove landscape of the Sine-Saloum Delta. We'll visit the bustling fishing district of Guet Ndar in Saint Louis, explore the city by horse-drawn carriage, enjoy the relaxed atmosphere of Gambia's capital, Banjul, and explore the Gambia River Delta by boat, with its tropical green riparian forests and the former slave island of James Island. On the beautiful coastal stretches of Cap Skirring and the Petite Côte, we'll feel like we're in paradise and recover from our eventful days. Itinerary – Day by Day Open all Day 1 – Tue., October 28, 2025 Flight to Dakar – Saly Flight to Dakar; onward journey to Saly "Bienvenue au Sénégal" From within Germany, you can reach your departure airport free of charge and in an environmentally friendly way. Our flight takes us from Frankfurt to Dakar. Our WORLD INSIGHT tour guide will meet us at the airport. A roughly one-hour transfer takes us to our accommodation in Saly. The ideal place for a relaxing start to our journey through these two exciting countries – far from the hustle and bustle of the big city. We check into our beach hotel on the Petite Côte. Distance: 30 km Overnight: Les Bougainvillées*** or Saly Princesse **(*) in Saly Meals: according to onboard service Day 2 – Wed., October 29, 2025 Saly – Joal-Fadiouth – Mbour – Saly Visit to Joal-Fadiouth and the Mbour fish market Shell Island, Joal-Fadiouth, and Fish Market in Mbour We'll start the morning off gently before setting off on our first exploration. In about two and a half hours, we'll drive to the idyllic shell island of Joal-Fadiouth, a wonderful example of the peaceful coexistence of Senegal's different religions. High up on the shell mountain is a cemetery where both Christians and Muslims are buried. Our destination for the early afternoon is the town of Mbour. The hustle and bustle of the fish market awaits us on the beach, and we marvel at the countless, brightly painted pirogues. In the late afternoon, we return to Saly, where we end the day at our beach hotel. Distance: 50 km Overnight: Les Bougainvillées*** or Saly Princesse **(*) in Saly Meals: B Day 3 – Thursday, October 30, 2025 Saly – Rufisque – Lac Rose – Dakar Visit a turtle breeding station in Rufisque and the Pink Lake, drive through the dunes of the Pink Lake, and stop at a turtle conservation project. Today, we travel via Rufisque and the salt lake Lac Rose to the capital, Dakar. In the city of Rufisque, we stretch our legs with a walk through the old town. Afterwards, we visit a "turtle village" – a conservation project where scientists and volunteers work to protect Africa's largest tortoise species. Finally, we reach the salt lake. Unfortunately, the famous Pink Lake recently lost its pink color due to severe flooding, and its salt content is now so low that even salt farmers can barely extract salt from the lake. The coming years will show whether the lake can restore its ecological balance. We'll take a short walk along the lake's shore and explore the surrounding area with our guide. We'll also take a trip to the dunes, which we'll do on the back of an old military vehicle. In the evening, we'll reach our accommodation in the capital, Dakar. Distance: 100 km Overnight: Casa Mara*** in Dakar Meals: B Day 4 - Fri., October 31, 2025 Dakar - Gorée Island - Dakar City tour in Dakar, excursion to the slave island of Gorée Vibrant capital We begin the day with a visit to the Tilène herb market and take in the many colors and smells. After a detour to the medina, where we meet the Lebou ethnic group, we board the ferry at midday to the former slave island of Gorée (a UNESCO World Heritage Site), which we reach after half an hour. On our approximately two-hour tour through the picturesque alleys, we also visit the 18th-century slave house "Maison des Esclaves" with its infamous staircase that separated the slaves from their tormentors and the "Door of No Return." From the castle, we then overlook the island and the skyline of Dakar. Back in the capital, we visit the pompous "Monument de la Renaissance Africanine" in the afternoon. Distance: 30 km Overnight: Casa Mara*** in Dakar Meals: B Day 5 – Sat., November 1, 2025 Dakar Visit to the fish market and further city explorations, visit to the Museum of Black Civilizations, afternoon free time Markets, museums, and history In the morning, we visit the Soumbédioune fish market. On a city tour, we see the famous Kermel market, the National Assembly, and the old colonial train station. We reach the Presidential Palace via Independence Square. Afterwards, we take time to visit the Musée des Civilisations Noires in Dakar. This ethnological and art museum is dedicated to Black civilization: The topics range from the earliest traces of human life to contemporary art. The afternoon is at your leisure, either for exploring the city on your own or for a relaxing end to the day at the hotel. Distance: 30 km Overnight stay: Casa Mara*** in Dakar Meals: B Day 6 - Sun., November 2, 2025 Dakar - Saint Louis Drive to Saint Louis with a stop in Thiès to visit an art exhibition and the market, further stop in the Mékhé commune, the fishing district in Saint Louis On the way to the old capital Today we set off for the old capital Saint Louis with its colonial heritage. It was the capital of French West Africa until 1902. After about a two-hour drive, we reach the city of Thiès. Here we visit a small art exhibition and stroll through the colorful market together. We make another stop in the Ngaye Mékhé commune, where we have the opportunity to have lunch together and visit a shoemaker who will demonstrate his craft. After that, we will travel for about another three hours by bus until we finally reach Saint Louis. In the fishing district of Guet Ndar in Saint-Louis, with its hundreds of colorful pirogues and its dried-fish stations, we'll get a glimpse of life on the Atlantic coast before settling into a hotel in the colonial center of the city. Distance: 265 km Overnight: Hotel de la Poste** in Saint-Louis Meals: B, L Day 7 – Mon., November 3, 2025 Saint-Louis – Djoudj National Park – Saint-Louis Half-day excursion with pirogue ride and birdwatching, followed by a horse-drawn carriage tour of the city. Pirogue ride in a bird paradise and colonial flair. Early in the morning, we travel into the steppes and bush savannahs of northern Senegal. Our destination is Djoudj National Park in the Senegal River Delta. We'll explore the world's third-largest bird sanctuary and a UNESCO World Heritage Site for around two hours by motorized pirogue. In the "green paradise of Djoudj," we will see numerous native species, such as flamingos and pelicans, as well as many migratory birds from Europe that winter here from November to March (don't forget your binoculars). On the return journey to Saint-Louis, we will pay a visit to the region's Peul farmers. Upon our return to Saint-Louis, horse-drawn carriages await us for our exploration of the historic center with its old colonial buildings (a UNESCO World Heritage Site). Distance: 60 km Overnight: Hotel de la Poste** in Saint-Louis Meals: Breakfast Day 8 - Tuesday, November 4, 2025 Saint Louis - Touba - Kaolack Mosque visit in Touba The "Holy City" of the Mourides Our journey continues into the south of Senegal. We will divide the long journey into two stages and take in a few sights along the way. On the way, we stop in the town of Touba, the center of the Mourides, where we can enter one of the largest mosques in West Africa (only outside of prayer hours). The town of Kaolack, located on the Saloum River, is our overnight destination. Distance: 290 km. Overnight: Relais Kaolack**(*) in Kaolack. Meals: B. Day 9 – Wed., November 5, 2025. Kaolack – Coubalan. Crossing Gambia and river crossing, Diola culture: Mask dance of Coubalan. Visiting the Diola, mask dance of Coubalan. Our destination today: the tropically green Casamance and the village of Coubalan. To avoid a long detour, we will cross the small enclave of Gambia today. The two border crossings will be an adventure in themselves. Don't worry, our tour guide knows the paperwork. Finally, we cross the mighty Gambia River – the namesake of the country we'll get to know more about over the course of our journey. After that, it's about another four hours to our destination for today: the village of Coubalan in Casamance. Here, the Diola people still live in close connection with nature and their cultural heritage. We'll spend the night in a very simple campement in the heart of the village, but this evening we'll experience something very special: the ethnic masked dance, in which the dancers adorn themselves with elaborate costumes, accompanied by rhythmic music and singing. The village community is preparing our dinner today. This is the start of several more days in which we'll get to know the culture of Casamance better. Distance: 250 km Overnight: Campement Coubalang in Coubalan Meals: B, D Day 10 – Thurs., November 6, 2025 Coubalan – Cap Skirring Village walks in Coubalan and Kathioune, learning about the traditional architecture and lifestyle of the Diola people Mighty Kapok Trees During a walking tour of the village of Coubalan, with a bit of luck, we might meet the village chief and have him show us the giant kapok trees with their powerful buttress roots that can be found in the village. On the way to Cap Skirring, we visit the village of Kathioune, where a knowledgeable villager shows us the well and a sacred tree. Animism is still widespread in Casamance, and many villages have sacred sites. We continue to Oussouye, where we meet a cooperative of disabled women who are active in handicrafts. With a little luck, we'll meet the only remaining traditional ruler of the Diola ethnic group, the "Mane," in Oussouye, who will tell us about the life of this remarkable community. In Mlomp, we'll learn about the region's extraordinary architecture and visit a two-story mud house. In the early evening, we'll reach Senegal's most beautiful stretch of beach at Cap Skirring. Distance: 150 km Overnight: Campement No Stress** or Hotel Maya** near Cap Skirring Meals: Breakfast Day 11 – Fri., November 7, 2025 Cap Skirring Swimming day at Cap Skirring beach or independent exploration Deeply relaxed on the beach Look forward to a perfect swimming day on the beautiful beaches of Cap Skirring, known for their long, soft sandy coastline and crystal-clear, warm waters. These beaches offer the ideal setting to take a break, unwind, and read a book under a palm tree. Use the time and plan your day as you wish. A lie-in, a stroll on the beach, or a refreshing swim – many things are possible today. Those who want to take the opportunity to visit the nearby town of Cap Skirring can take a taxi to experience some of the city's everyday life. Route: - Overnight: Campement No Stress** or Hotel Maya** near Cap Skirring Meals: B Day 12 – Sat., November 8, 2025 Cap Skirring – Ziguinchor Open-Air Museum Sangawatt, Sacred Tam-Tam in Siganar, Visit to the Impluvium House in Enampore Immersion in Diola Culture This morning we visit the traditional open-air museum of Sangawatt, dedicated to the culture and animist traditions of the Diola. The museum director will introduce us to the history and way of life of this ethnic group and familiarize us with their animist religion. Afterwards, we will drive towards Ziguinchor. First, we marvel at the village's sacred tam-tam in Siganar, a traditional instrument of communication between the villagers and the neighboring villages. Afterwards, we visit the impluvium house in Enampore and reach our destination for today in the late afternoon. Ziguinchor, the trading center of Casamance, still captivates with its colonial flair. Our centrally located accommodation allows those who are adventurous to explore the town on their own in the evening or go out for dinner. Otherwise, the hotel has a small, cozy courtyard that invites you to linger. Perhaps you'd like to take a dip in the pool! Distance: 190 km Overnight: Le Flamboyant** in Ziguinchor Meals: B Day 13 – Sun., November 9, 2025 Ziguinchor – Kassagne Border crossing into Gambia, guided walk or bike tour Pure nature along the Gambia River After about 90 kilometers, we cross the border into Gambia. The small country is completely surrounded by Senegal and was once colonized by Great Britain. At midday, we reach our accommodation in Kassagne, beautifully situated on a tributary of the Gambia River, and have some time to ourselves. In the afternoon, we experience the nature and villages along the mighty river on our guided easy walk or a short, easy mountain bike tour. Distance: 120 km Overnight: AbCa's Creek Lodge*** in Kassagne Meals: B Day 14 – Mon., November 10, 2025 Kassagne Boat tour on the Gambia River, afternoon free time On the Gambia River The Gambia River and its tributaries meander majestically through the picturesque landscape of West Africa, providing a beautiful backdrop for our days in the small enclave of Gambia. On our boat tour today, we'll keep an eye out for the colorful birdlife and perhaps encounter some curious monkeys that live here in the mangroves. We'll spend the second half of the day in the relaxed atmosphere of the lodge right on the riverbank, treating ourselves to some time off. Route: - Overnight: AbCa's Creek Lodge*** in Kassagne Meals: B Day 15 – Tuesday, November 11, 2025 Kassagne – Banjul Walk in the Makasutu Cultural Forest, Monkey Forest, afternoon free time on the Atlantic Ocean Visit to the Monkey Forest We'll drive westward for one to two hours along dusty tracks along the Gambia River. South of Banjul, we'll stop at the Makasutu Cultural Forest, where we'll take a walk and marvel at the flora and fauna of the nature reserve and enjoy a simple lunch. Continuing our journey, we'll stop at the Bijilo Monkey Forest, where the residents will greet us cheerfully. Our hotel is located in the immediate vicinity, near the beach in one of Banjul's suburbs. There's still time for a swim in the Atlantic Ocean. Distance: 90 km Overnight: Mansea Beach** or Cape Point** near Banjul Meals: B, L Day 16 – Wed., November 12, 2025 Banjul City Tour and Market Visit The Cultural Heart of Gambia Look forward to a cultural and historical exploration! Banjul is manageable, and the sights are within walking distance. We'll walk through the city center, past July 22nd Square, along the main shopping street, Liberation Avenue, to the famous Albert Market. Along the way, we'll climb the stairs to Arch 22, from which we'll have a good view of the city. Afterwards, we'll visit the Jamah Mosque and the small National Museum. Afterward, we'll head to the city market. We'll stroll through the narrow streets and explore the colorful stalls with a variety of goods, including handmade crafts, local textiles, spices, fresh fruit and vegetables, and traditional African clothing. We'll end the day in the evening at our hotel on the Atlantic Ocean. Distance: 50 km Overnight: Mansea Beach** or Cape Point** near Banjul Meals: B Day 17 – Thursday, November 13, 2025 Banjul – James Island – Toubakouta Ferry ride across the Gambia River, visit to James Island, border crossing into Senegal Transatlantic Slave Trade First, we drive to Banjul and take the ferry across the Gambia River to Barra, then continue upstream to a small jetty. From here, we board a passenger boat to James Island, an island in the heart of the Gambia River. Here, we delve into the fascinating past of this UNESCO World Heritage Site. As an important trading post during the transatlantic slave trade, the island served as a hub for the exchange of goods and people. We explore the well-preserved ruins and learn about dark chapters of history as we walk through the former fortifications and slave cells. At the same time, we enjoy the picturesque beauty of the surrounding river landscape and are impressed by the significance and complexity of this historical site. Back on land, we continue by bus across the border in Karang to Toubakouta. Back in Senegal, we reach the mangrove landscape of the Sine-Saloum Delta in the afternoon. Since 2011, the national park, with its many small islands and waterways, has been a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Our accommodation is located directly on the water, and after the long bus ride, we find some peace and quiet by the pool. Driving distance: 125 km Overnight: Keur Saloum**(*) near Toubakouta in the Sine-Saloum Delta Meals: B Day 18 – Fri., November 14, 2025 Sine-Saloum Delta Learn about the palm wine harvest and sustainable oyster fishing, explore the Sine-Saloum Delta by pirogue The Spirits of the Serer and Mandinka Today, in the heart of the bush, we will gain an insight into the palm wine harvest, where skilled harvesters climb dangerously to the treetops to collect the palm wine in bottles. In the village of Sangako, we will meet women from a cooperative who, after a short walk to the mangroves, will tell us about ecologically sustainable oyster fishing. We will also explore the beauty of the Sine-Saloum Delta with its lagoons, small islands, mighty baobabs, and mangrove forests aboard a pirogue. We sail through this peaceful and natural world and enjoy the numerous birds that call it home. We then discover a small shell island where the deceased Serer and Mandinka were buried (their spirits are said to still be here today). Enjoy stunning views before we explore the small tributaries of the delta by pirogue and, with a little luck, observe birds such as pelicans, kingfishers, bee-eaters, weaver birds, and red-necked falcons. Route: - Overnight: Keur Saloum**(*) near Toubakouta in the Sine-Saloum Delta Meals: B Day 19 – Sat., November 15, 2025 Sine-Saloum Delta – Saly Village visits on the way to the Petite Côte, with a communal farewell dinner in the evening Conclusion at the Petite Côte We spend the last days of our trip on the Petite Côte. Along the way, we'll visit a few villages to interact with locals and stretch our legs. Halfway through, in Foundiougne, we'll cross the Sine River one last time and approach the palm-fringed coastline south of Dakar. Endless sandy beaches stretch out here, inviting you to relax and enjoy the tropical sun. The perfect end to an eventful trip through Senegambia. A farewell dinner will be held in the evening. Today is your last day with your tour guide, as tomorrow we'll be spending time on the beach. Distance: 165 km Overnight: Les Bougainvillées*** or Saly Princesse **(*) in Saly Meals: B, D Day 20 – Sun., November 16, 2025 Saly – Dakar – Return flight Beach day or time for independent exploration and return flight Beach relaxation and return flight Today everyone has time to stroll along the beach again, enjoy the sea, and jump in. We'll take it easy before our flight and allow ourselves time to unwind. Day rooms are still available at the hotel (one room for four guests each). From Saly, the international airport is just under an hour away. Au revoir, Sénégal! Distance: 40 km Overnight stay: Airplane, one day room for four people each at Les Bougainvillées*** or Saly Princesse **(*) in Saly Meals: Breakfast Day 21 – Monday, November 17, 2025 Arrival Arrival and Departure Back Home We usually arrive in Frankfurt around lunchtime. You can reach your hometown by train, which is environmentally friendly and free of charge within Germany. Distance: - Overnight stay: - Meals: as per onboard service Tour guide Lamine, 68, was born in Senegal. He studied both English and German at the University of Dakar. He has been working as a tour guide for Senegal and Gambia for over 25 years. It is a great pleasure for him to show our groups his country with all its cultural diversity and to let us experience the hospitality of the Senegalese. Lamine Seck is one of our WORLD INSIGHT tour guides in Senegal and the Gambia. Travel Information Open all Entry Requirements & Vaccinations Senegal: A passport valid for at least 6 months beyond the end of the trip is required. A valid yellow fever vaccination is officially required for all arrivals from a yellow fever area (according to the WHO, Gambia is a yellow fever infection area). Vaccinations against yellow fever, hepatitis A, and poliomyelitis are recommended. Depending on individual indications, additional vaccinations against dengue fever, hepatitis B, meningococcal ACWY, rabies, and typhoid are recommended. A cholera vaccination is generally not necessary. Gambia: A passport valid for at least 6 months beyond the end of the trip and a visa are required. You will receive the visa upon entry. A valid yellow fever vaccination is officially required for all arrivals from a yellow fever area (Senegal is a yellow fever infection area according to the WHO). Vaccination against hepatitis A is recommended. If individually indicated, additional vaccinations against dengue fever, hepatitis B, meningococcus ACWY, rabies and typhoid are advised. A cholera vaccination is generally not necessary. Note: The entry regulations apply to German, Austrian and Swiss citizens. We will be happy to provide information to other EU citizens after they have provided their nationality, or they can find out more directly here. Unless otherwise stated, at least a machine-readable passport valid for 6 months at the end of the trip and with two blank, facing pages is required. Citizens of other nations outside the EU should contact their responsible authority. Requirements & travel-specific information No special requirements. Normal physical fitness and health are sufficient. A high degree of adaptability, openness, and tolerance is expected on this trip, as the journey often takes place over poor roads and some overnight stays are simple. Road conditions change constantly, even at short notice, which is why we cannot provide reliable information on travel times and why minor changes to the program may occur. The itinerary includes numerous visits to families, artisans, artists, initiatives, etc. Please note that individual program items may vary or even be omitted. Occasionally, these spontaneous visits cannot be arranged due to personal or other reasons on the part of the hosts. The tour guide will endeavor to accommodate such cases. We ask for an openness to spontaneity, as this is the only way the trip can maintain its character as a journey of encounters with plenty of contact with locals. For the mountain bike tour on day 13, simple men's bikes will be provided, the condition of which may not always meet current safety standards. Meals: Breakfast is included daily on this trip, and dinner on some days as well. Vegetarians are asked to note this when registering. You will find the meals marked in the trip description with B=breakfast, L=lunch/picnic, D=dinner. On-site team Our cheerful team with Bijou and Abdoulaye supports our Country Manager Khalifa in the office in Dakar. Together with them, we planned our varied Senegal and Gambia trip down to the last detail, as they are our on-site experts. Khalifa has always been passionate about bringing his country's culture closer to travelers, and so he opened his agency in 2004. Our German-speaking Senegalese tour guides have many years of experience, spent several years in Germany, and speak good German. They will show you their homeland with commitment, professionalism, and even more fun, so that you will always remember it. Our team in Senegal and Gambia Khalifa, our Country Manager in Senegal and Gambia Local transport In Senegal and Gambia we use typical local minibuses, which can vary in size depending on the group size. The buses usually have air conditioning and windows that open. Luggage is usually carried on the roof. At Pink Lake, we take a trip in an old military vehicle. There are no seatbelts here. One of our minibuses in Senegal and Gambia. One of our minibuses in Senegal and Gambia. One of our minibuses (interior view) in Senegal and Gambia. These two West African countries are an insider tip for anyone seeking adventure, exciting cultures, stunning natural landscapes, and incredibly hospitable people. Read more: Travel report: Senegal. More than a desert rally. On Uta Gramme's journey through multifaceted Senegal, the sounds of drums and dance rhythms were a constant companion – she tells of encounters with villagers, the diverse natural landscape, and the slave island of Gorée! Read more: Other tours in the region: Senegal adventure tour. The jewel of West Africa. Senegal is one of the most touristically developed countries in West Africa and offers ideal conditions for a relaxing holiday with many cultural and scenic highlights. 15 days from €2,699. scraped_itos.title: Senegal & Gambia | African Travel Semin
scraped_itos.description: Cultural and historical tour from Dakar to, Goree Island, the Pink Lake, and Abuja Nature Reserve. Also relax at Saly and enjoy water sports, beach and great cuisine. Spend a few days in The Gambia visiting sites in Banjul, Serekunde, and Bakau. Visit markets, artisans, museums and more.
scraped_itos.content: Senegal & GambiaAlex Haley’s book, Roots, is focused on The Gambia. In Senegal you must visit Goreé Island, a departure point for many Africans who were sold into slavery. The Door of No Return is the museum preserving its history. Cultural villages, forests, festivals, birdlife and one of the best cuisines in West Africa.

scraped_itos.title: Resor till Gambia | Hitta din nästa vinterresa | Apollo
scraped_itos.description: Res till Gambia med Apollo i vinter. Gambia lockar med vackra stränder och massvis med upplevelser! Hitta och boka din resa smidigt och enkelt på apollo.se
scraped_itos.content: GambiaSe alla länderÖversiktHotellFaktaVäderRestipsBildgalleri(1/44)Bildgalleri(1/44)Under din resa till solsäkra Gambia kan du se fram emot avkopplande dagar fyllda med sol och bad på de långa och härliga sandstränderna. Utforska den rika kulturen och upplev de färgstarka och livliga marknaderna. Gambia hälsar dig välkommen med allt som behövs för en avkopplande, upplevelserik och minnesvärd semester!Populära hotell - GambiaSe allaKombo Beach ResortGambiaPer person från 11 089 krCape Point HotelGambiaPer person från 9 195 krBalafon Beach ResortGambiaPer person från 11 093 krBungalow BeachGambiaPer person från 9 512 krMer om resmåletDen vänliga lokalbefolkningen hälsar dig varmt välkommen till Gambia, även känt som "the smiling coast". Hit har semesterfirande skandinaver rest sedan 1960-talet för att uppleva allt från soldränkta stränder och spännande utflykter till lokala marknader och det genuina vardagslivet.Gambia ligger i västra Afrika, öster om Kap Verde och delar gräns med Senegal som omger landet förutom längs kustlinjen.Långa sandstränderSe fram emot avslappnat strandhäng och lata dagar i solstolen på någon av Gambias härliga och kilometerlånga stränder. De finkorniga sandstränderna är både många och stora - perfekt för dig som vill breda ut dig och slippa trängas. Under eftermiddagen när temperaturen sjunkit något samlas människor på stranden för att spela fotboll, promenera eller bara njuta av den vackra solnedgången.På söndagar beger sig lokalbefolkningen till stranden för en dag fylld av umgänge och avkoppling. Picknickkorgar packas och stranden blir en samlingsplats där människor umgås, badar, spelar fotboll och äter mat tillsammans.Sevärdheter & naturupplevelserGambia är mycket mer än bara långa sandstränder! Utforska landets fantastiska djur- och naturliv som sträcker sig lång bortom kustremsan. Vad sägs om att ta en båttur på Gambiafloden och spana in flodhästarna i sin naturliga miljö eller varför inte upptäcka det rika fågellivet i de imponerande mangroveträsken?Vill du upptäcka det autentiska Gambia rekommenderar vi ett besök på den spännande landsbygden. Där kan du utforska lokala marknader och det vardagliga livet.Restauranger och nöjeslivNjut av god mat på någon av alla lokala och internationella restauranger. Prova några av de lokala rätterna Benachin, en ris- och skaldjursrätt eller den populära chili- och jordnötsgrytan, Domada.Gambia erbjuder även ett brett utbud av riktigt bra libanesiska restauranger, så passa på att utforska det utsökta libanesiska köket under sin semester.När det kommer till nattklubbar och barer finns allt från enkla strandbarer, trevliga loungebarer till livliga nattklubbar som har öppet till långt in på småtimmarna.Apollos hotell & resmål i GambiaPå många av våra resmål runt om i världen kan du bo längs med stranden, men i Gambia bor du bokstavligen på stranden!Reser du till Gambia med Apollo har du möjlighet att välja bland flera fina hotell och områden längs den vackra Atlantkusten. Vill du bo ”där det händer” rekommenderas våra hotell i Kololi och speciellt området Senegambia som bjuder på en livfull atmosfär med ett uttalat nöjesliv, ett brett utbud av restauranger som erbjuder allt från libanesisk till italiensk mat, och många trevliga barer.I Kotu-området väntar en av Gambias finaste stränder och trots att flera hotell ligger vid stranden finns det gott om plats för alla. För de som vill bo med bästa strandläge är sporthotellet Kombo Beach Resort ett utmärkt val, här trivs både träningsentusiaster och barnfamiljer, som båda kan njuta av hotellets många bekvämligheter och aktiviteter. I Kotu finns också ett par restauranger, små butiker och mysiga barer att utforska.I området Cape Point bor du nära både stranden och det lokala livet, vilket ger dig möjlighet att upptäcka och handla färsk frukt och hantverk på de lokala marknaderna. För en extra lugn och avslappnad semester rekommenderar vi området Bijilo, bortom Gambias lite större turistområden. Här kan du ta dagen som den kommer och se fram emot sköna dagar i solstolen.Utflykter med ApolloVill du upptäcka mer av Gambia har du även möjligheten att följa med på flera av våra härliga och spännande utflykter som finns bokningsbara på Mitt Apollo. Du kan bland annat följa med till naturparken Senegal Fathala Park, där du kan få se giraffer, zebror och noshörningar. Lär du dig hellre mer om den lokala maten kan du följa med på en matlagningskurs.Fakta om GambiaTidsskillnadSvensk tid -1 timme vintertid, svensk tid -2 timmar sommartid.ValutaDalasi (GMD). I Gambia är det viktigt att ha kontanter med sig då kortbetalning inte accepteras överallt. Det är möjligt att växla pengar i de flesta hotellreceptioner, men för en bättre växlingskurs rekommenderas att besöka växlingskontoren runt omkring, det finns många. Det finns också växlingskontor på flygplatsen. Vill du ta ut kontanter på plats finns även flera uttagsautomater runt om i området.Transfer till resmåletTransfer från flygplatsen till Apollos hotell tar ca 45 minuter.StränderStränderna i Gambia är både breda och flera kilometerlånga med härligt finkornig sand. Notera att undervattensströmmar kan förekomma och vi rekommenderar att du inte simmar allt för långt ut. På stränderna längs Atlantkusten kan även större vågor förekomma. Håll koll på flaggorna på stränderna för att se om det är säkert att bada.VäderServicenivåApollo Service LinePå resmål med Apollo Service Line kan du, dygnet runt, komma i kontakt med oss via telefon, sms och mejl, som besvaras av skandinavisk- och engelsktalande Apollo personal. Är ärendet brådskande bör kontakten alltid ske via telefon.Reser du med ett flyg i reguljärtrafik och har beställt transfer så blir du mött av en lokal representant som hjälper dig till hotellet. scraped_itos.title: Gambia Birding Tours - Birding Ecotours
scraped_itos.description: Gambia birding tours are seen as great introduction to African birding and will surely leave you yearning for more from this amazing birding and wildlife
scraped_itos.content: Gambia Birding Tours Go to: Senegal birding tours | Birding tours to Africa and its islands | All our Birding Tours Gambia birding tours are seen as a great introduction to African birding and will surely leave you yearning for more from this amazing birding and wildlife continent. The Republic of The Gambia (“The Gambia” hereafter) is the smallest country of mainland Africa. The entire country is surrounded by Senegal, except for the west coast which sits on the Atlantic Ocean. The Gambia really is a tiny country at just 4,127 square miles (10,689 square kilometers) which would make it the third smallest mainland US state, just behind Connecticut. The Gambia’s population is around 2.2 million people, about the same as New Mexico, with around 413,000 people living within the urban area of the capital, Banjul. Banjul is a relatively modern city, only being founded in 1816, and was the center when The Gambia was a colony of the British Empire. The first records of The Gambia are from the 9th and 10th centuries when the area was visited by Arab traders from North Africa. Later The Gambia became part of the Mali Empire, before the Portuguese Empire arrived and sold the trade rights of The Gambia to the British Empire, ruled by Queen Elizabeth I. During the 17th century the British Empire and French Empire fought for control of the region before Britain finally invaded and occupied the country in 1758. While France retained some control, what remained was ceded to Britain in 1856. The modern boundaries of The Gambia were formed in 1889 and The Gambia finally gained independence from Britain in 1963. Read More About Gambia During the three centuries of the transatlantic slave trade, it is thought that as many as three million people were transported from The Gambia and the surrounding region to colonies across the world. In 1807 the British Empire abolished the slave trade but failed in doing this in The Gambia until 1906. The geography of the Gambia is dominated by The Gambia River which flows down the spine of the country. The surrounding land is flat and a mixture of savanna, forest-savanna, and mangroves. The Gambia is only 31 miles (50 kilometers) wide at its widest point and as such the climate is consistent across the country. The tropical climate brings rain between June and November along with high temperatures. From November until May the climate is dry, and temperatures are lower. The Gambia’s bird list is currently 620 species (following International Ornithological Congress (IOC) taxonomy v11.1 in May 2021), an incredible total for such a small country. There are obviously far too many species to list here but some of the many highlight species from our The Gambia: Gateway to Africa tour include Egyptian Plover (a most-wanted bird for many world birders and a monotypic family), African Paradise Flycatcher, African Pygmy Goose, Hamerkop (another monotypic family), Guinea Turaco, Violet Turaco, Northern Carmine Bee-eater, Swallow-tailed Bee-eater, Oriole Warbler, White-spotted Flufftail, African Finfoot, Abyssinian Ground Hornbill, Martial Eagle, African Fish Eagle, Bateleur, Red-necked Falcon, Marabou Stork, Pygmy Sunbird, Exclamatory Paradise Whydah, Black Crowned Crane, Long-tailed Nightjar, Blue Malkoha, Green-headed Sunbird, White-crested Helmetshrike, Splendid Starling, White-breasted Cuckooshrike, Grey-headed Kingfisher, Pel’s Fishing Owl, African Wood Owl, Greyish Eagle-Owl, Verreaux’s Eagle-Owl, White-backed Night Heron, Spotted Honeyguide, Bronze-winged Courser, Red-throated Bee-eater, Four-banded Sandgrouse, Stone Partridge, and much more. We will also come across a wide range of Western Palearctic migrants during our Gambia birding tour including many passerines, shorebirds (waders), herons, bitterns, egrets, birds of prey, and swifts. It promises to be a wonderful birding experience. This Gambia birding tour is designed to be the perfect introduction to African birding. We will be staying in the famous Senegambia Beach Hotel during our time on the coast which offers all the facilities of the best hotels in Europe. With the bonus of around 230 species of birds recorded in the hotel grounds and immediate area, it also allows for excellent photo opportunities. When we travel upriver, we will stay in comfortable and safe eco-lodges with the birds again on our doorstep, and while on our journey we make use of safe and comfortable vehicles. Gambia: Winter Escape Birdwatching Holiday January 2026/2027 View More Download Gambia ItinerariesGambia: Winter Escape Birdwatching Holiday January 2026/2027Gambia Gallery View Larger Egyptian Plover View Larger Abyssinian Ground Hornbill View Larger Black-faced FirefinchMattias Hofstede View Larger African Finfoot View Larger Goliath Heron View Larger Bateleur View Larger Hamerkop View Larger Northern Carmine Bee-eater View Larger Pel's Fishing Owl View Larger Palm-nut Vulture View Larger Saddle-billed Stork View Larger White-crowned Lapwing View Larger Swallow-tailed Bee-eater View Larger African Fish Eagle View Larger Black HeronMattias Hofstede View Larger Spotted HoneyguideMattias Hofstede View Larger White-crested Helmetshrike View Larger Martial Eagle View Larger Yellow-crowned Gonolek View Larger Senegal Parrot Testimonials from our Gambia birding tours Senegal and The Gambia is a delightful destination and is full of birds. For those that have not experienced Africa before, it is an excellent introduction to African birding. The river trips are wonderful and it is difficult to know where to look first with bee-eaters, kingfishers of multi colors assaulting the mind. Dylan is a very able leader whom we enjoy travelling with as his African birding knowledge is first class as well as having a delightful personality well able to overcome problems that inevitably arise in African countries. The climate of sun and heat is a welcome relief of grey, cold miserable weather experienced in the northern hemisphere in winter. Accommodation is basic but adequate and local eateries are interesting but would not win any medals for hygiene. Sue - On Senegal/The Gambia and Dylan - December 2022

Over Gambia Foto's & video Home Gambia Kalimba Beach Resort Balafon Beach Resort Ocean Bay Vakantie Gambia: ‘the Smiling Coast of Africa’ De altijd stralende zon, kleurrijke bevolking en het exotische natuurschoon maken van Gambia een geweldige vakantiebestemming. Gambia staat beter bekend als ‘the Smiling Coast of Africa’. En dat is niet zonder reden! Ontdek zelf de tropische stranden, oprechte gastvrijheid en de culturele pracht van Afrika en boek nu je vakantie Gambia bij Corendon! Goedkope vakantie Gambia Hoewel Gambia het kleinste land van Afrika is, heeft het een grootse natuurlijke schoonheid. De 70 kilometer lange kustlijn met hagelwitte zandstranden is alleen al een goede reden om voor een vakantie Gambia te kiezen. Heerlijk zonnen op het strand, relaxen met een cocktail in je hand… Maar Gambia biedt veel meer dan zon, zee en strand. Trek ook het binnenland in en bewonder de uitgestrekte mangrovebossen waar onder andere meer dan 450 verschillende soorten vogels leven. Gambia vakantie informatie Weer Gambia Gambia is een tropisch vakantieparadijs met warm zeewater, wuivende palmbomen en ruim 7 tot 8 uur zon per dag. Van november tot en met mei kun je tijdens een vakantie Gambia genieten van een gemiddelde temperatuur van 21 tot 27 graden. En de zon, die schijnt het hele jaar door! Het is dan ook niet zo vreemd dat Gambia een geliefde winterzonbestemming is. Bekijk onze uitgebreide informatie over het klimaat van gambia. Gambia bezienswaardigheden Varen over ‘The Gambia’ De belangrijkste toeristische attractie van Gambia is de gelijknamige rivier ‘The Gambia’. Deze rivier is de levensader van Gambia en stroomt over de volledige lengte van het land. Het is een absolute must om een boottocht te maken tijdens je vakantie Gambia. Het water wordt omzoomd door de groene jungle, waar je vogels en misschien zelfs ook nijlpaarden of krokodillen kunt spotten. Afdingen op de markt in Banjul Wil je het echte Gambiaanse leven proeven? Doe dan je boodschappen op de markt! Struin door smalle straatjes met zelfgemaakte kraampjes en tik bijzondere souvenirs op de kop. Je kunt het zo gek niet bedenken of het is te koop: etenswaren, kleding, witgoed… Aanraders om te bezoeken tijdens je vakantie Gambia zijn de Albert Market in Banjul of de Serrekunda Market in Serrekunda. Hotels en Appartementen in Gambia Corendon heeft een gevarieerd aanbod aan appartementen en hotels in Gambia. Corendon heeft alle accommodaties met grote zorg geselecteerd om je vakantie Gambia zo aangenaam mogelijk te maken. Bij de selectie van de accommodaties wordt onder andere gelet op de ligging t.o.v. stranden, eetgelegenheden en eventuele stadscentra. lees meer Kaart Vluchtinfo 7,7 Gem cijfer, 2296 beoordelingen va. Heerlijk uiteten op de Strip en vervolgens een dansje wagen met de ritmische Gambianen. Tip: bezoek het binnenland tijdens een excursie om het echte Gambia te ontdekken." Gerelateerd Meer vakanties in Gambia Alle vakanties Gambia Luxe vakantie Gambia All Inclusive Gambia Last minute Gambia Hotels Gambia Gambia met kinderen Algemene informatie Hoofdstad: Banjul Aantal inwoners: 1.883.051 (2013) Oppervlakte: 11.295 km2 Taal: Engels Religie: 90% Islamitisch, 9% Christelijk Tijdsverschil: 2 uur vroeger in de zomer, 1 uur vroeger in winter Munteenheid: Dalasi Regeringsvorm: Republiek Elektriciteit: 220V, 50 hertz wisselstroom BNP per hoofd: $2.000 (2011) Landnummer: +220 Lokale noodnummers: Ambulance 116, politie 117, brandweer 118 Eten en drinken In de vakantiegebieden zijn de meeste restaurants helemaal op de toeristen ingesteld. Je hebt er keuze uit allerlei restaurants, van Chinees tot Mexicaans. In de steden kun je heel goedkoop Afrikaans eten, maar wees voorzichtig en let goed op de hygiëne! Men gebruikt in Gambia veel rijst, kip en vis, bereiding geschiedt meestal op een vuur. Het water dat in Gambia uit de kraan komt is in veel hotels van redelijk goede kwaliteit, maar het drinken ervan wordt afgeraden. Daarom is ons advies om flessen mineraalwater te kopen. Een van de weinige fabrieken in Gambia is de Banyul Brewery, hier wordt het goed drinkbare Gambiaanse bier Julbrew (groene flesjes) gebrouwen. Taal Engels is de officiële taal in Gambia, met name bij de overheid, in het onderwijs, in de rechtspraak en natuurlijk in de toeristencentra. Ruim de helft van de Gambianen spreekt naast Engels een eigen stamtaal.Natuur Gambia is een paradijs voor vogelliefhebbers. Er werden tot nu toe ongeveer 450 verschillende soorten geteld, en nog steeds worden nieuwe soorten ontdekt. Helaas zijn alle grote zoogdieren vrijwel allemaal uitgestorven door de jacht die in de 19 de eeuw op ze gemaakt werd. De welbekende 'African Big Five' zal je in Gambia niet vinden want olifanten, neushoorns, giraffen, leeuwen, buffels, grote antilopen, hebben hun heil ergens anders gezocht. Diep landinwaarts komen nog wel nijlpaarden en krokodillen in de Gambia rivier voor. Verschillende kleine apensoorten zoals de fluweelaap en de huzaaraap komen overal voor. Chimpansees leven alleen nog in het Baboon Island National park. Verder zijn er nog kleine antilopensoorten, aardvarkens en wrattenzwijnen. Gambia heeft een aantal nationale parken en reservaten waar deze dieren te bewonderen zijn.Feestdagen 1 januari: Nieuwjaar 14 februari: Onafhankelijkheidsdag 27 februari: Hemelvaart Mohammed (Isra en Mi'raj) 28 februari – 30 maart: Ramadan 8 maart: Internationale Vrouwendag 30 maart: Suikerfeest (Eid al-Fitr) 6 juni: Offerfeest (Eid al-Adha) 5 september: Geboortedag Mohammed (Milad un-Nabi) 25 & 26 december: Kerstmis 31 december: OudjaarAchtergrond / Geschiedenis De vroegste schriftelijke verwijzing naar Gambia is vastgelegd in het verslag van Hanno de Carthaag. De Carthagen leefden ongeveer 470 voor Christus in het oude Europa / Middellandse Zeegebied en maakten vele intercontinentale reizen en stonden zo in contact met verre beschavingen. Het eerste Portugese contact met Gambia werd gelegd in 1456 toen een Portugese verkenningsvloot op het huidige James Island landde. Zij vestigden handelsposten waar zij zout, ijzer, buskruit en geweren verhandelden in ruil voor ivoor, goud, ebbenhout en slaven. Begin 17e eeuw kampten de Portugese kolonies in Brazilië met een arbeiderstekort, wat er toe leidde dat dit tekort aangevuld werd vanuit West Afrika door middel van slaven. Hierna volgden de Nederlanders en de Fransen het voorbeeld waardoor Portugal zijn monopolistische positie verloor. De slaven werden tewerkgesteld in onder andere Amerika, Jamaica , Suriname en de Antillen. In 1661 namen de Britten definitief bezit van James Island en dit was het begin van de Britse heerschappij over Gambia. De Fransen namen bezit van wat tegenwoordig Senegal is. Pas in 1807 werd onder Britse heerschappij de slavernij afgeschaft, maar de Britten bleven Gambia wel bezetten. Na de Tweede Wereld Oorlog kwamen er steeds meer stemmen voor zelfbeschikking, maar pas op 18 februari 1965 kreeg Gambia politieke onafhankelijkheid van Groot-Brittannië. Op 24 april 1970 werd Gambia een zelfstandige republiek. Duurzamer op vakantie Écht duurzame vliegvakanties bestaan helaas nog niet. Maar als je je voetafdruk een (klein) beetje wilt verkleinen, kun je bij het boeken van je vliegvakantie Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) kopen. Wat dat precies is lees je hier. Met het kopen van SAF draag je bij aan een lagere CO2-uitstoot van je vliegreis. Je kunt daarnaast kiezen voor een gecertificeerde accommodatie. Deze hotels voldoen aan de hoogste duurzaamheidsstandaarden en zijn daarom een betere keuze voor je vakantie. Maak je gebruik van een transfer naar je hotel? Gemiddeld genomen vervoert een bus meer mensen dan een taxi, waardoor de CO2-uitstoot per passagier lager wordt. Een bustransfer is daarom vaak een duurzamere keuze dan een privétransfer. Op de bestemming Gambia ligt aan de westkust van Afrika en is volledig ingesloten door Senegal. De natuurlijke omgeving van Gambia wordt gekenmerkt door de Gambia-rivier die dwars door het land stroomt. Langs de rivier en de zee vind je mangroves en een overvloed aan vogel- en vissoorten. De mangroves zijn belangrijk, want ze vormen natuurlijke barrières tegen bodemerosie. Het is belangrijk om je te realiseren dat Gambia een land is dat voor grote uitdagingen staat als het gaat om natuurbescherming, armoede en gelijke rechten. Als je Gambia bezoekt, zal je zien dat er veel afval langs de weg ligt en dat mensen in armoedige huizen of op straat leven. Het kan daarom even schakelen zijn als je uit het vliegtuig stapt. Maar de meeste Gambianen zullen je met open armen ontvangen. In Gambia zijn de meeste mensen moslim. De vrouwen zijn vaak gesluierd. Het is respectvol om zelf ook bedekkende kleding te dragen, vooral als je de toeristische gebieden uit gaat. Muziek en dans spelen een centrale rol in het Gambiaanse leven en lokale festivals en vieringen zijn vaak gevuld met traditionele muziek en kleurrijke dansuitvoeringen. Schroom niet om zelf mee te dansen, de Gambianen zijn vriendelijk en verwelkomen je graag. Bewust op excursie Hoewel je op onze bestemmingen tal van avontuurlijke excursies en activiteiten kunt ondernemen, is het belangrijk om je bewust te zijn van de mogelijke impact ervan op de natuur en cultuur. Over het algemeen geldt: zo lang je mensen, dieren en natuur respectvol behandelt, kun je met een gerust hart van je vakantie genieten. Klik hier voor een overzicht van handige do's en don'ts tijdens excursies. De Gambiaanse mangroves kun je het beste bewonderen vanuit een kayak. Er zijn verschillende nature reserves die je in Gambia of het naastgelegen Senegal kunt bezoeken. Ook een batikworkshop is een aanrader: hier leer je hoe typisch Afrikaanse stoffen worden bedrukt. Als je meer wilt leren over de geschiedenis van het land kun je James Island en het Fort James bezoeken. Het binnenland van Gambia geeft een andere kijk op het land. Spreek een lokale taxichauffeur aan om je erheen te brengen en je de mooiste plekjes te laten zien. Maatschappelijke impact Er zijn verschillende manieren om de lokale bevolking of de natuur op je vakantiebestemming te helpen of te ondersteunen. Vraag je lokale reisleiding naar zijn of haar tips voor goede doelen of sociale initiatieven. Iedere bestemming heeft namelijk eigen uitdagingen op het gebied van klimaat of maatschappelijke kwesties. Corendon steunt in Gambia de Bakau Basketball Academy (BBA): een plek waar jongeren iedere dag van de week samen kunnen sporten onder begeleiding van twee oud-profbasketballers. Veel kinderen in de achterstandswijken van Banjul missen rolmodellen in hun directe omgeving. Dankzij de BBA hebben ze de nodige afleiding en krijgen ze perspectief. De Nederlandse Ed Spier reisde al vier keer op onze kosten naar Gambia om de BBA te helpen groeien. Vluchtduur De vluchtduur naar de luchthaven van Banjul bedraagt ca. 6.15 uur. Bekijk de vliegtijd naar Gambia. Je dient er rekening mee te houden dat de hierboven genoemde vluchttijd slechts ter indicatie is en er altijd tijdspelingen mogelijk kunnen zijn.Transfer De transfer naar je accommodatie is niet inbegrepen, maar optioneel bij te boeken. Klik hier voor meer informatie en de kosten. Transfertijd Vanaf Banjul luchthaven naar: Bijilo: ca. 20 minuten Kololi: ca. 25 minuten Kotu: ca. 30 minuten Cape Point: ca. 40 minuten Banjul: ca. 40 minuten Je dient er rekening mee te houden dat de hierboven genoemde tijden slechts ter indicatie zijn en er altijd tijdspelingen mogelijk kunnen zijn. Legitimatie Klik hier voor alle informatie over legitimatie, een eventueel visum en formaliteiten op het gebied van gezondheid. Verkeer Het autoverkeer in Gambia is onveilig door onder andere de slechte staat van de wegen en voertuigen. Bij een ongeluk krijgt de chauffeur meestal de schuld. Houd er bovendien rekening mee dat er nergens verkeersborden staan.Openbaar vervoer Reizen met het openbaar vervoer in Gambia is alleen aan te bevelen aan de ervaren reiziger. Er is een busnetwerk en er varen verschillende veerboten waarmee je de Gambia Rivier kunt oversteken.Taxi Men kan drie soorten taxi's vinden in Gambia: De bushtaxi: een busje welke dient als een soort openbaar vervoer en zeer goedkoop is. De groene taxi: deze is bedoeld voor toeristen en mogen je ook in het toeristengebied ophalen. Het is verstandig van tevoren de ritprijs af te spreken. De gele taxi's: bestemd voor privé vervoer voor Gambianen, deze mogen niet in het toeristengebied komenAutohuur Autohuur in Gambia is mogelijk maar wordt afgeraden gezien het chaotische verkeer. Tijdsverschil Het is in Gambia tijdens onze wintermaanden 1 uur vroeger en tijdens onze zomermaanden 2 uur vroeger.Geldzaken De Gambiaanse munt is de Dalasi (D), onderverdeeld in 100 Bututs. Er zijn (beperkt) munten van 1, 5, 10, 25 en 50 Bututs en er is een munt van 1 Dalasi. Bankbiljetten zijn er van 5, 10, 20, 25, 50, 100 en 200 Dalasi. In Gambia vind je op een beperkt aantal plaatsen pinautomaten, die creditcards (alleen Visa en Mastercard) en Maestro-bankpassen (moeten ‘aan’ staan voor buiten Europa) accepteren. Houd er rekening mee dat het aantal automaten beperkt is en buiten bedrijf kunnen zijn, door bijvoorbeeld storingen. Met een bankpas kan alleen geld uit een automaat gepint worden, met een creditcard kan naast het geld pinnen uit een automaat ook betaald worden bij hotels, sommige restaurants en excursies. Het blijft verstandig ook contanten bij je te hebben. Je kunt je euro's ter plaatse omwisselen in de hotels of bij speciaal daarvoor bestemde wisselkantoren die veelvuldig te vinden zijn in het toeristengebied. Let daarbij op de koers. Deze kan per locatie variëren. Je kunt ook je excursies betalen met een creditcard of bankpas. Houd er dan wel rekening mee dat de kosten in de meeste gevallen hoger uitkomen. Ook de bank in Nederland kan nog een vergoeding voor een betaling buiten de eurozone vragen. Je kunt dit voorkomen door contante euro’s mee te nemen. In dit geval dien je wel te bedenken dat het meenemen van grote hoeveelheden contant geld risico’s met zich meebrengt en dat het geld bij verlies of diefstal niet verzekerd is. Zet je pinpas ‘aan’ Voor je veiligheid hebben de meeste banken betaalpassen standaard geblokkeerd voor gebruik buiten Europa. Als je op vakantie gaat buiten Europa kunt je je pinpas kosteloos ‘aan’zetten bij je bank. De bank kan je meer informatie geven. Accommodaties en borg Let op! Het is gebruikelijk in Gambia dat bij aankomst in de accommodatie een borg wordt gevraagd, deze kun je doorgaans met cash of creditcard voldoen. Tijdens je verblijf kun je met deze borg consumpties ‘op rekening’ bestellen. Wel zo handig! Elektriciteit Het voltage in Gambia is 220 Volt, adapters kun je het beste vanuit Nederland meenemen. Het zijn Engelse stekkerdozen dus reisstekkers zijn gewenst.
marketing_text: Vakantie Gambia: ‘the Smiling Coast of Africa’
services: Entreegelden voor excursies en safari’s inbegrepen

scraped_itos.title: Gambia Holidays | 2025 / 2026 | FirstChoice.co.uk
scraped_itos.description: If you're looking for a great value holiday to Gambia, check out our exclusive online deals from First Choice. Book online today!
scraped_itos.content: Search HolidaysRecommended HotelsExperiencesAll DestinationsFind Out MorePopular Holidays Holidays to The Gambia have exotic wildlife, palm-packed beaches and haggle-friendly markets in the bag. Bite-sized AfricaSqueezed onto Africa’s west coast, The Gambia’s basically taken a chunk out of Senegal’s shoreline. Savannahs and sandy beaches, baboons and buffalos, markets and mangroves – it packs a culture-blazing itinerary. Plus, its small size is actually a perk – it means you can cram more sights into one break. Not only that, but it’s only six hours away and in the same time zone as the UK, and the official language is English, so you get winter sun without the stress. Chimps and crocsThe Gambia goes wild with wallowing hippos, chimps swinging along the Gambia River and Nile crocodiles at the Kiang West National Park. Africa's known for its safaris, and this spot doesn’t disappoint, either. Tonnes of nature reserves and national parks let you inside these animals’ natural habitats, at a respectful distance, of course. Look up, too. The Abuko Nature Reserve alone is home to more than 300 species of exotic bird to suit you twitchers. Beach lifeWhen you’re not wildlife-watching, you can be sunbathing on strips of sand. Kotu and Kololi are both top resorts – Kololi is backed by a big strip of bars and foodie places, as well. But the wildlife is never far away. In Bakau, Cape Point beach rolls down to the bird-squawking wetlands of Cape Creek. And on the other side of the river, Jinack Island’s 11-kilometre stretch of au naturel shoreline will have you dreaming up your desert island discs selection. Post-sunset shenanigansDaytimes in The Gambia are at the chilled end of the scale – wildlife-watching and sunbathing will probably take up a big chunk of space on your itinerary. Come nighttime, though, there’s no shortage of bars, clubs and restaurants to get your teeth into. Kololi’s the country’s nightlife hub. Here, the famous Senegambia Strip buzzes with energy after dark – once a row of roadside shacks, it’s now the go-to spot for eating out, mingling with the locals and late-night clubbing. Off-beat adventuresLike a lot of developing countries, The Gambia comes with a few unique charms – but they’re all part of the authentic experience. The roads are on the bumpy side, Wi-Fi isn’t always as reliable as what you’re used to at home, and not all hotel lobbies and restaurants have air con. You’ll probably notice the odd power cut during your stay, too. However, all of this makes for an adventure to remember – and the smiling locals, tropical shores and off-the-beaten-track experiences you’ll get here will more than make up for the lack of mod-cons. scraped_itos.title: Gambia Senegal Wildlife Tour | Fleewinter Destination
scraped_itos.description: Explore Gambia and Senegal's diverse wildlife on this immersive tour, encountering vibrant birdlife, primates, and unique ecosystems.
scraped_itos.content: Gambia Senegal Wildlife Tour | Fleewinter Destination Request a quote Notice: JavaScript is required for this content. × Search Gambia & Senegal Wildlife Tour 8 days from £2,320 per person The Gambia & Senegal Wildlife Tour makes a fabulous introduction to the wildlife of Africa and, for bird lovers, it’s an absolute must. See monkeys, giraffes, zebra and more, not to mention some of the 540-plus species of birds found here. This exciting itinerary combines three unique places to stay, a floating river lodge deep in the heart of Makasutu Forest, a small boutique hotel by the beach and glamping in a Senegalese wildlife reserve. We recommend a minimum of 8 days, but longer itineraries are also available. Suitable for couples and families with children 16 years and older. Itineraries for families with younger children are also available. Your Itinerary Day 1 - Arrive in The Gambia Arrive in the afternoon at the Banjul Airport where your driver will meet you for your transfer (45 minutes) to the stunning Mandina Lodges in the heart of Makasutu Forest. Here you’ll find your floating lodge on a tributary of the River Gambia. That evening, dine alfresco under a thatched cabana beneath a star-studded African sky. Accommodation Day 2 - Explore Makasutu forest and waterways Having enjoyed a coffee or tea on your verandah watching the forest awake, head out for a walk with your guide and learn more about the flora and fauna of the area including the large troop of baboons that live here. Once back at the lodges, take a leisurely late breakfast and spend the rest of the day relaxing by the river or the pool, watching the birds that regularly visit. In the late afternoon, your guide will take you out in a canoe to explore the mangroves and waterways. As well as the varied birdlife, you’ll see local fishermen and, at low tide, women collecting oysters from the exposed mangrove roots. Accommodation Day 3 - Sunset cruise On your second morning, head out with your guide along the river by canoe or on another forest walk, perhaps visiting the Gambia Horse and Donkey Trust. Chat to one of their volunteers for a fascinating insight into the work of this charity. In the late afternoon, join other guests at Mandina for a cruise along the river in a motorboat to see flocks of birds coming home to roost as the sun sets behind the mangroves while enjoying a bottle of South African house wine (one bottle per couple). Accommodation Day 4 - Go wild in Senegal Start the day early with a private transfer to Banjul’s ferry port from where you’ll cross the River Gambia. This is an adventure in itself with a colourful collection of vehicles, people, and often animals streaming onto the ferry. Your guide will look after you all the way. From here it’s just a short drive across the border to Senegal and Fathala Wildlife Reserve. Staying in luxury safari tents, with air-conditioning and an ensuite bathroom, you’ll soon settle in. That afternoon set off on a sunset game drive through the African bush for the chance to see the rare West African giant derby eland as well as zebra, giraffes, rhino, buffalo, warthogs, several species of monkeys and numerous bird species. Accommodation Day 5 - Discover Senegal Visit a traditional Senegalese market and bakery and learn about local life. Meet local artisans, see traditional crafts and fabrics, taste baobab juice and be back at Fathala in time for lunch. In the late afternoon, join a guided walk through the Africa bush to learn about the plants and smaller animals that live on the reserve. This is an excellent opportunity for bird photography. There’s no guarantee what you may see, but frequently sighted bird species include the Abyssinian roller, the rose-ringed parakeet, the western red-billed hornbill, the long-tailed glossy starling and many more. Accommodation Day 6 - Back to The Gambia It’s time to return to The Gambia and transfer to Leo’s Beach Resort set in an elevated position overlooking a quiet sandy beach. The rest of your day is free to spend relaxing by the pool or the beach. Alternatively, the nearby village of Tanji is a short taxi ride away. Here you can see the local fishing boats known as pirogues being unloaded and watch the hustle and bustle of the fish market. It’s a mesmerising, colourful sight set against a cacophony as gulls squawk overhead, and people haggle over the price of fish. Accommodation Day 7 - Birdwatching Rise early to make the most of your time with your birding expert. If there’s a particular habitat or species you’re interested in, let us know; otherwise, leave it to your guide to take you to the best birdwatching location on any specific day. Likely sites include Abuko Nature Reserve, home to approximately 250 species of birds, including giant kingfishers and turaco; Brufut Forest for its array of woodland birds, or nearby Tanji Bird Reserve, not far from your hotel. Accommodation Day 8 - Bid farewell to the Smiling Coast of West Africa After a leisurely breakfast, with plenty of time for a walk along the beach or a last swim in the pool, leave Leo’s Beach Resort around mid-morning to check-in for your flight home. Details - This Gambia & Senegal Wildlife Tour itinerary costs from £2,320 per person based on 2 sharing. What's included? Includes: Prices start from £2,320 per person Fullboard at Mandina Lodge and Leo’s Beach Hotel; and B&B at Fathala Wildlife Reserve Transfers (including ferry crossing) An English-speaking guide available throughout your stay Fathala Wildlife Reserve game drive, village visit and bushwalk All trips are ATOL protected or ABTA bonded to ensure you are fully covered Make a booking Ngala Lodge A unique, cliff-top boutique hotel with stunning ocean views and one of the finest restaurants in The Gambia. More Coco Ocean Resort & Spa The elegant Moroccan inspired Coco Ocean, by a tranquil neverending beach, is one of the most luxurious hotels in The Gambia. More Leo's Beach Hotel This intimate, contemporary eco-friendly hotel boasts excellent sea views from it’s elevated position by a quiet golden sand beach. More White Horse Residence An eco-friendly, tranquil retreat with seven thatched lodges in a lush green tropical garden overlooking the ocean and a beautiful sandy beach. More Ocean Bay Hotel A well-established, family-friendly hotel by one of the best beaches in The Gambia. More Mandina Lodge A unique, tranquil hideaway, these stunning eco-lodges on a tributary of the River Gambia, lie deep in the heart of Makasutu Forest. More Fathala Wildlife Reserve See zebra, giraffes, monkeys, rhino and more while glamping at this wildlife reserve in Senegal, just across the border from The Gambia. More African Princess Beach Hotel A unique and contemporary hotel by a beautiful beach in South Kotu. We particularly love the swim-up ground floor rooms. More Your adventure starts here! Do you fancy having a chat about Gambia & Senegal Wildlife Tour? Personally, it's one of our favourite things to talk about. scraped_itos.title: Gambia Holidays 2025 / 2026 - Hays Travel
scraped_itos.description: Gambia…The Smiling Coast of Africa!
scraped_itos.content: Gambia Gambia Holidays Gambia…The Smiling Coast of Africa! Holidays in The Gambia Gambia is a small West African country bordered by Senegal on three sides with a narrow Atlantic coastline and is known as ‘The Smiling Coast of Africa’ thanks to the warm and friendly welcome you’ll receive from the locals. Gambia is perfect for laid-back beach holidays on endless, uncrowded swathes of golden sands alongside the 50-mile-long shoreline. You’ll also get to experience the country’s rich and diverse history, amazing natural beauty, thrilling activities, eclectic wildlife, and authentic cuisine. And, what’s more, Gambia is only just over six hours flying time from the UK and is on the same time-zone, so no jet-lag! When is the best time to visit Gambia? Gambia offers a sub-tropical climate with between six to 12 hours of daily sunshine throughout the year and average monthly temperatures between 24oC and 27oC. The country also has two distinct seasons – the dry season from November to May and the wet season from June to October. Where is the best place to stay in Gambia? Discover an array of places to stay in Gambia to suit every budget. Beach-lovers flock to the main resorts of the long-established Kololi and the vibrant and newly developed Kotu, while nature lovers can check into floating lodges on the River Gambia. Whether you’re seeking bed and breakfast, self-catering, half-board, or all-inclusive; Hays Travel will find you the best accommodation for your Gambia holiday. Travel guide The Gambia is popular with all ages and tastes including families, couples, friends, and single travellers. From sun-worshippers and activity fans to avid explorers and culture enthusiasts, holidays to Gambia have something for everyone. Best time to visit: November-May Average flight time: 6 Hours 20 Minutes Most suited for: Couples Currency: Gambian Dalasi Time Difference: -1 Hour BEACH LIFE AND CITIES Spend a relaxing morning or afternoon enjoying the African sunshine and swimming in the azure ocean that laps the golden stretches of sands in the vibrant resorts of Kololi and Katu. If you’re seeking splendid isolation, escape to the less-crowded and secluded beaches at Cape Point and Brufut. City-wise you can head to the capital Banjul on St Mary’s Island, where Gambia meets the Atlantic Ocean – here you can admire the colonial buildings like the Gambia National Museum, shop for local handicrafts at lively Albert Market, and admire the architectural marvel of Arch 22, the gateway to the city. THINGS TO SEE AND DO! Tee off in the sunshine on the fairways of Koloki Golf Course and Fajara Golf Club. With over 600 species of birds indigenous to Gambia, it’s a birdwatcher’s delight, so don’t forget your binoculars. Follow the walking trails through Abuko Nature Reserve to spot Vervet, Western Red Colobus, and Patas Monkeys. Get up close to the 100 crocodiles who live in Katchikally Crocodile Pool and take a relaxing cruise past birds, wildlife, and mangroves on the Gambia River. Head to Bakau to pick up woodcarvings at the craft market or see how fabrics are made on a visit to Serekunda Batik Factory. Delve into the nation’s rich and vivid history at the iconic Kunta Kinteh Island, Wassu Stone Circles, and Fort Bullen. Food & Drink Prepare to embark on a culinary journey that celebrates the rich cultural heritage of The Gambia. From traditional Gambian dishes to international cuisines like Italian, Chinese, Indian, and Lebanese; the dining scene is a fusion of flavours that will delight your palate. Typical dishes you’ll see on local menus include Akara (black-eyed pea fritters), Benachin (one pot stew with fish or chicken), Domoada (peanut-based dish), freshly-baked Talapa bread, and Yassa (chillies, limes, onions, mustard, and stock) with beef, fish, prawns, or vegetables. Non-alcoholic drinks to sample include Baobab Juice and Wonjo Juice and also the mildly-alcoholic Palm Wine.
