scraped_itos.description: Exclusive online discounts for Gambia holidays at Holiday Hypermarket. ABTA and ATOL protected and rated 4.7/5 by our customers. Huge discounts waiting!
scraped_itos.content: Gambia Holidays 2025/2026We’ll say it up front – Gambia isn’t your average holiday destination. With gold sand beaches, an incredible wealth of wildlife, energetic craft markets and some of the friendliest locals you’re bound to meet on your travels, this little African country is in a holiday genre of its own. TRAVEL AWARE – STAYING SAFE AND HEALTHY ABROAD (foreign office travel advice)Gambia Holiday Deals 2025/2026 View more dealsThe smiling coast of AfricaGambia is a slim country along the western coast of mainland Africa, hugged almost completely by Senegal, minus its narrow coastline. It’s the smallest country in all of Africa, named after the river snaking through the land. Gambia first entered the sights of tourists after a group of Scandinavian holidaymakers catapulted it onto the scene in the sixties, but the country itself did the rest. Holidays to Gambia combine swathes of beaches with exotic wildlife, and locals so welcoming that the country has earned itself the nickname ‘the smiling coast of Africa’. Key Facts for Gambia: Currency: Gambian Dalasi (GMD) Language: English Timezone: GMT +0 Avg. Flight Time: 5 hours 30 minutes (from London) Visas: You do not need a visa if you’re travelling to Gambia for up to 28 days. RegionsBijiloCape PointKololiKotu BeachFurther ReadingArticlesBest HotelsFood And Drink Location Where is Gambia? Where's best to stay in Gambia?From lively beach resorts to peaceful coastal escapes, Gambia’s top regions each offer something unique, whether you’re after wildlife, nightlife or sun-soaked relaxation. Beaches in GambiaGambia’s coastline offers sun-soaked escapes with a mix of lively beaches and tranquil stretches. Bijilo Beach is a peaceful spot with soft sands and gentle waves, perfect for families or couples. Nearby cafes and small restaurants serve traditional local dishes, and you might even spot monkeys from Bijilo Forest Park nearby. Cape Point features golden sands and calm Atlantic waters, ideal for swimming, splashing around with the kids or a quiet stroll. Its rocky backdrop and scenic views make it a photographer’s dream. Kololi Beach is a lively and bustling option, lined with sunbeds and a promenade full of bars, restaurants and shops. It’s the heart of Gambia’s beach life, perfect for those seeking a social vibe with plenty of amenities on hand. Kotu Beach stretches for miles, offering a quieter, natural escape. You can explore tidal pools, spot birdlife in the mangroves, or simply relax on the soft sand with the gentle surf. It’s perfect for nature lovers or those looking for their own tranquil spot. Wildlife in GambiaGambia has some of the best wildlife reserves and forests in West Africa, making it a fantastic destination for nature lovers and animal enthusiasts alike. Just south of Cape Point in the town of Bakau is the Kachikally Crocodile Pool, a sacred site where crocodiles glide through the water. Traditionally used for fertility rituals, it’s also a fascinating place to see these ancient reptiles up close. The Bijilo Forest Park, also called Monkey Park, is a protected area home to playful monkeys, diverse birdlife, and shaded walking trails – perfect for a peaceful nature stroll. A short drive south of Banjul takes you to the Abuko Nature Reserve, Gambia’s first official wildlife reserve. Here you’ll encounter monkeys, reptiles like crocodiles and cobras, and more than 200 bird species, making it a birdwatcher’s paradise. For those seeking a true African adventure, head on a safari excursion from Kololi or Banjul, along the Gambia River or into the bush. Spot hippos, giraffes, lions, and other iconic wildlife in their natural habitat, making for an unforgettable experience. Craft markets in GmbiaLocal craft markets are the heart of any Gambian city. Here, locals display their wares, fresh fruits and vegetables pile high, and you’ll see the iconic visual of women balancing wicker baskets atop their heads. Cape Point Markets are small but charming. At the Bakau Craft Market, you’ll find stalls selling handmade jewelry, textiles, and souvenirs, perfect for picking up unique keepsakes while experiencing local life. The markets in Kotu Beach offer a mix of beachfront shopping and local culture. The Kotu Craft Village is a standout, with colorful fabrics, handmade crafts, and tropical fruits, giving visitors a taste of authentic Gambian crafts. Senegambia Craft Market in Kololi has a lively community vibe. Stalls are packed with traditional carvings, paintings, and woven goods, while street performers and local musicians add to the energetic atmosphere, giving a true taste of Gambian culture. Albert Market in Banjul is the country’s largest and most famous market. It’s a bustling hub of activity, where you can haggle for leather goods, wooden carvings, spices, and local delicacies. Places to go in GambiaGambia may be small, but it’s packed with attractions that will give you a taste of the local culture, nature and beach charm. In Kololi, Bijilo Forest Park is a huge (51 hectare!) coastal reserve renowned for its rich biodiversity. Stroll through the trails that wind through the dense forest and catch glimpses of vervet monkeys, red colobus monkeys, and over 130 bird species. It’s a tranquil escape for nature enthusiasts and families seeking a blend of wildlife and coastal beauty. The Senegambia Strip is the heart of Kololi’s vibrant tourist scene. This bustling area is lined with a variety of shops, restaurants, bars, and nightclubs, offering a lively atmosphere, whether you’re after an evening stroll, some local cuisine, or the energetic nightlife. If you love natural charm and local culture, head to Kotu Beach for leisurely walks and birdwatching. Browse the markets, sunbathe on the soft sand or try your hand at beach volleyball and soak up the serene surroundings. Things to see in GambiaFrom historic landmarks to hidden gems, Gambia offers a range of sights that capture its culture, history, and natural beauty. Arch 22 is an iconic arch that commemorates the 1994 coup and offers panoramic views over Banjul and the Gambia River. It stands 36 metres high so climb to the top for the incredible photo-worthy views and with a cafe and museum here too, you can appreciate Gambian history with a nice treat. The Bakau Botanical Gardens offers a peaceful oasis perfect for a romantic stroll. The gardens are brimming with tropical plants, palm trees, and serene pathways giving you an escape from the bustling towns. It’s ideal for families or nature lovers, or if you’re looking for an afternoon out of the beaming sun. To explore more of Gambia, head to Tanji, particularly the Tanji Village Museum. It’s a small but fascinating museum showing Gambian fishing culture and history, with traditional boats, tools and exhibits on local life. Nightlife in GambiaGambia’s nightlife is lively but relaxed – the ultimate combo. With options ranging from beach bars and live music venues to bustling clubs and local cultural evenings, you can expect a bit of everything. Nightlife in Bijilo is low-key, with a handful of beach bars and small restaurants offering live music and cocktails. It’s the perfect place for couples or friends looking for a relaxed evening with ocean views. Cape Point is also a quieter, scenic area with intimate nightlife. Expect sunset dinners followed by a few drinks and a peaceful atmosphere. Kololi is the heart of Gambia’s party scene. The Senegambia Strip comes alive at night with bars, nightclubs, and live entertainment, ideal for younger party crowds or anyone seeking energetic nightlife, cocktails and music until late. Kotu Beach offers a good mix of casual beach bars and lively venues, with live music and friendly atmospheres. It’s a great pick for families and friends wanting a lively night out without the bustle of Kololi. Gambian cuisineGambian cuisine is a hearty and flavourful mix of West African, Portuguese, and French influences, shaped by the country’s rivers, fertile land and coastal access. Expect a huge focus on dishes with rice, seafood, plantain and aromas of garlic, onions and tomato. Domoda is a rich peanut butter stew made with meat, fish, or chicken and vegetables, usually served with rice. Considered as Gambia’s national dish, it’s a must try for anyone wanting an authentic taste of local flavours. Street food in Gambia is popular for affordable lunches and snacks, like fish rolls – fried fish in soft bread – fataya – deep-fried pastry pockets filled with spiced meat or fish – and even kebabs, with grilled beef, chicken or seafood. Desserts in Gambia are often simple and sweet with a focus on local ingredients like peanuts and tropical fruits including mango, papaya and pineapple. You can expect to find sweet treats in my food stalls and local cafes, perfect for an afternoon snack or after your evening meal. Drinks in GambiaGambia has a variety of traditional drinks that reflect its culture, climate and local ingredients, perfect for refreshing yourself while basking in the beaming sunshine. Baobab Juice is a tangy, vitamin-rich drink made from baobab fruit pulp and often served chilled. It pairs well with grilled fish, fried snacks or light meals for a refreshing balance. The perfect accompaniment for your spicy evening meal, Bissap is a sweetened hibiscus flower drink – sometimes flavored with mint or ginger, it perfectly compliments the bold flavours of your meal. Attaya is a Gambian Tea – a strong green tea brewed with sugar and traditionally enjoyed with biscuits, cakes or peanut-based sweets. Perfecting attaya is a long process involving pouring the tea from a height, several times and between cups, to create three different strength teapots. Palm Wine is a mildly alcoholic, lightly sweet drink tapped from palm trees and it’s a great compliment to any seafood or meat dish. Costs in GambiaPrices in Gambia can vary depending on where you are, but here are some typical average costs: A three-course meal for two at a mid-range restaurant can cost around £35–£55. Food from street vendors is much cheaper, usually less than a few pounds. A bottle of local beer might cost around £1.40, a soft drink about £1.10, a glass of wine £4–£5, and cocktails in the more upscale bars £6–£8. A short taxi ride of about 5 km during the day would typically cost around £4.50. How much could some typical excursions in Gambia cost me? Head on a half day tour around Gambia’s capital, Banjul, exploring the sights and history for around £50 per adult and £20 per child. Enjoy an evening preparing and eating an evening meal with a local family in their home, for around £30 per person. Frequently asked questions about holidays to GambiaWhat is the best time to go to Gambia?Make the most of the country’s amazing, stunning beaches during the dry season and enjoy average temperatures of around 24 degrees celsius across the coastal areas. Whatever time of the year you choose for your holiday to Gambia, you can rest easy knowing that you will experience tropical temperatures with sunshine all around you. Is Gambia expensive?Look to book an all inclusive holiday Gambia and everything will be included in your price from drinks and food to flights, hotels and transfers. Local supermarkets offer you the chance to pick up little bits such as snacks and any essentials you may have forgotten, all at relatively cheap prices too. Does Gambia have beaches?It certainly does and they’re often quiet, serene places where you can unwind and relax in the sunshine. Along the coastal areas you’ll find beautiful sandy beaches that are just waiting for you to explore them. With an amazing climate, friendly locals and so much wildlife on offer throughout the country, you can either choose to relax by the sea or explore inland some more. Why is Gambia popular with tourists?As there is so much to do in The Gambia, there is never a dull moment. There’s so many activities to dive into as well as the beautiful surroundings you will find yourself in. Many tourists love the diverse wildlife on offer and with the opportunity to see this first hand you can rest assured your holiday is going to be memorable. What are the hottest months in Gambia?Around May time are the hottest parts of the year when it comes to a holiday to The Gambia. As you head out of the dry season and into the wet season you can experience higher temperatures such as in August but you run the risk of rain, although it can be quite refreshing during soaring temperatures! What is the currency in Gambia?The currency in Gambia is the Gambian Dalasi (GMD). This is a closed currency which means you can only buy and sell your travel money once you’re in the country, and before you leave again. What language do they speak in Gambia?The most common spoken language in Gambia is English, although you are likely to hear many tribal languages, like Mandinka and Wolof. What is the time difference between the UK and Gambia?Gambia shares the same timezone as the UK, GMT +0, so there is no time difference. How long is the flight from the UK to Gambia?The average flight time from the UK (London) to Gambia is 5 hours 30 minutes. This can vary depending on where you’re flying from. Do I need a visa to travel to Gambia?For holidays up to 28 days in Gambia you do not need a visa. For holidays longer than 28 days,you can get an extension – find out more information.

scraped_itos.description: Discover a biological paradise of unique landscapes and wildlife on a small group trip to The Gambia.
scraped_itos.content: The Gambia tours & holidaysThe smallest country in continental Africa leaves a big, big impressionAlthough petite in size, The Gambia is a powerhouse of biodiversity. With an abundance of different ecosystems and nature reserves, you don't have to travel far to see some amazing wildlife. Although this part of West Africa is a birdwatchers' paradise with over 600 species of birds, you'll also want to be on the lookout for Nile crocodiles, hippos, spitting cobras and monkeys. Your camera is a non-negotiable for a trip to the Gambia.Our The Gambia trips Refine search Senegal & The Gambia Adventure 12 days Original From GBP £2,376Build your dream adventure Let's create an exclusive trip for your group. Explore tailor-made trips Get inspired on The Good Times Read all stories Guides5 West African countries that should be on your radarThe Goods 2025: New trips & experiences7 new ways to make a difference as you travel with Intrepid The Goods 2025: New trips & experiences12 new ways to get closer to nature with Intrepid The Goods 2025: New trips & experiences8 of the best traditional foods to try in West Africa The Goods 2025: New trips & experiences9 new experiences for beach lovers and island hoppers Read all stories We also travel toTogoSenegalBeninGhanaThe Gambia at a glance CAPITAL CITYBanjul (population 480,000)POPULATION2.7 millionCURRENCYGMDLANGUAGEEnglish (official), Wolof, Mandinka, FulaTIME ZONE(GMT) CasablancaCALLING CODE+220ELECTRICITYType G (Irish/British 3-pin) Type C (European 2-pin) Learn more about The GambiaBest time to visit The GambiaBest time to visit The GambiaThe best time to visit Gambia is from November to February when temperatures are pleasant, and there’s little humidity. Conveniently, this is also the best time to spot birds and wildlife as the country is green and lush.The average temperature rises between mid-February and April, and humidity can be oppressive. Intense periods of rain have been known to wash away some of the roads.Geography and environmentGeography and environmentCompletely surrounded by Senegal save for its 80-kilometre stretch of coastline, the Gambia is an exceptionally flat country. The highest point is only 53 metres above sea level. The country’s namesake river begins in the east and travels among tropical rainforests before gradually giving way to mangrove swamps and coastlines. Further from the river, savannahs and plantation woodlands dot the landscape.Top 5 Gambian drinksTop 5 Gambian drinks1. BissapBlood-red and extremely sweet, bissap (or manjo) is an infused herbal tea made from the flowers of the hibiscus plant, and it’s the nation’s number one drink. Typically flavoured with ginger or mint, it makes for a refreshing midday beverage. And with preliminary studies recently suggesting that it may reduce blood pressure, you may well return home in better shape than you left.2. AtaayaAs much a social rite as a no-holds-barred caffeine injection, try the three-glass Ataaya ceremony when you’re looking to recharge the batteries or make some local friends. One part Chinese green tea leaves to two parts sugar, three parts water and a bunch of mint – think of it as the teetotaller’s mojito.3. KinkelibaBrewed from the leaves of the local Kinkeliba plant, this strong, sweet herbal tea is mostly drunk as a breakfast tonic or at dusk during Ramadan when its appetite-stimulant qualities assist in gorging on the evening meal.4. BouyiA thick, syrupy juice made from the fruit of the baobab, this ultra-sweet libation imparts an unmatched sugar high and is certainly more appetising than its ungainly tree would have you expect.5. JulBrewDescribed by some beer buffs as evoking aromas of hay, boiled vegetables, canned corn and cardboard, Gambia’s national beer is probably unlikely to scoop any international beer awards. But knocked back on a white sandy beach while being buffed by delightful sea breezes, you’re hardly likely to care.The Gambia travel FAQsDo I need a visa to travel to The Gambia?Most nationalities will need to obtain a visa in advance to travel to The Gambia.Visas are the responsibility of the individual traveller. Entry requirements can change at any time, so it's important that you check for the latest information.You can check the entry requirements for your nationality on your government's foreign travel advisories, consular websites or on our visa and entry requirements page.Do I need to purchase travel insurance before travelling?Absolutely. All passengers travelling with Intrepid are required to purchase travel insurance before the start of their trip. It's important to understand that each country you visit may have its own specific entry requirements, and some destinations mandate travel health insurance for all foreign travellers, regardless of their nationality.Your leader will record your travel insurance details on the first day of the trip. Due to the varying nature, availability and cost of health care around the world, travel insurance is an essential part of every journey.Read more about travel insuranceIs tipping customary in The Gambia?A 10% service charge is usually added to the bill in established restaurants, bars, hotels and taxis — but feel free to tip more than this for exceptional service. At restaurants where a service charge isn’t included, 10% is the acceptable gratuity. Although tipping at other places isn't mandatory it will be much appreciated given the low wages that Gambian service workers are typically paid. Setting aside a small amount for porters, guides and drivers is also a good idea.Can I drink the water in The Gambia?Tap water isn't safe to drink in The Gambia. Hotels and lodges will often provide filtered water, and your local leader is always available to help. Water filtration tablets are often helpful for peace of mind.What is the internet access like in The Gambia?The internet connection can be a little slow in some remote areas, especially in towns further inland. Hotels, cafes and bars in Banjul usually have wi-fi with reliable connectivity.Can I use my mobile phone while in The Gambia?Mobile phone coverage is good in The Gambia’s large cities and towns but less so in rural areas. If you plan to use your mobile phone, ensure you have global roaming activated or download an eSIM before leaving home.What is ATM access like in The Gambia?ATMs can be found at banks in urban areas like Banjul and Serrekunda, though they aren’t always reliable. Due to credit card and bank fraud, caution is advised when using these, and some ATMs may only allow withdrawals of fairly small amounts.Are credit cards accepted in The Gambia?The Gambia is primarily a cash-based economy. Credit cards are generally only accepted at top-end hotels and at some high-end restaurants in Banjul. We recommend you carry enough local currency on your trip.What are the toilets like in The Gambia?Fairly clean western-style toilets can generally be found in Banjul and the towns on the Atlantic Coast. In towns and villages further inland, squat/pit toilets are the norm. Carry your own supply of soap and toilet paper, as this is rarely provided.How do I stay safe and healthy while travelling?We take the health and safety of our travellers seriously and take every measure to ensure that trips are safe, fun and inclusive for everyone. When you travel with us, you have access to our global support network and local on‑ground leadership, and you can rest easy knowing we have a zero-tolerance policy on discrimination.We recommend that all travellers check with their government or national travel advisory organisation for the latest information before departure. The World Health Organisation also provides useful health information.Travelling from Australia?Go to: Smart TravellerFrom Canada?Go to: Canada Travel InformationFrom the UK?Go to: UK Foreign Travel AdviceFrom New Zealand?Go to: Safe TravelFrom the US?Go to: US Department of StateLearn more about safe travels with IntrepidSMALL GROUP TRAVEL THAT'S GOOD ALL OVERWe're here to do good by creating positive change through the joy of travel.We're here to do good by creating positive change through the joy of travel.Our purposeOur purpose

scraped_itos.content: Manage My BookingFAQFlights + HotelHotelsDeparture airportAny airportWhenAny dateHow long7 nightsRoom(s)1 Room / 2 AdultsSearchAny airport / 7 nights / 1 Room / 2 Adultsexpand search formSearchCheck-in - Check-outAny dateRoom(s)1 Room, 2 Adults SearchGambia HolidaysUTC+00:00GMD: Gambian dalasiEnglishDiscover the hidden gem of West Africa with a holiday to The Gambia. This small but mighty country packs a punch when it comes to unique experiences and breathtaking landscapes. With its stunning sandy beaches, lush tropical forests and vibrant culture, The Gambia is a haven for intrepid holidaymakers.Nature lovers will be in their element exploring the diverse wildlife of Kiang West National Park or cruising down the majestic River Gambia. For a taste of local life, head to the bustling markets of the capital Banjul where you can haggle for kaleidoscopic textiles and handcrafted souvenirs. Meanwhile, history buffs won't want to miss a visit to Jufureh, the ancestral home of Kunta Kinte, a fictional character from the novel and TV show, Roots.With its warm hospitality, delicious cuisine and laid-back atmosphere, The Gambia is the perfect choice for those seeking a relaxing beach break with a difference. Soak up the sun on the golden sands of Kololi Beach or take a dip in the crystal clear waters of the Atlantic Ocean. And with year-round sunshine and temperatures rarely dipping below 30°C, it's also an ideal winter sun destination.Read moreWhy book Gambia holidaysBeautiful beachesUnwind on the golden sands of Kololi Beach and take a dip in the crystal-clear Atlantic waters.Great national parksExplore the diverse wildlife and breathtaking landscapes of Kiang West National Park.Bustling shopping sceneHaggle for colourful fabrics and handmade trinkets at the buzzing markets in the capital Banjul.Top attractionsAlbreda, Juffureh, and Kunta Kinteh Island are collectively designated a World Heritage Site by UNESCO.Cultural hotspotGo to the Makasutu Cultural Forest for traditional music and dance, canoeing along the river and more.Delicious local foodTantalise your taste buds with delicious Gambian cuisine, from fresh seafood to spicy stews.Best places to stay in GambiaKotuOne of Gambia’s most popular tourist spots, Kotu holidays provide a wide range of attractions. The natural beauty of the area attracts guests of all ages. The beach area is a fantastic place to relax and soak up the African…From£689ppKololiKololi is on the Atlantic coast on Gambia, surrounded by the beautiful Bijilo Forest Park, which is a fantastic place to appreciate local plants, wildlife, and spot vervet monkeys. The resort has a fantastic ambiance and is the perfect setting…From£729ppBijiloBijilo is a beautiful resort, with unspoilt beaches and no nightclubs to disturb the peace, just a few beach bars that illuminate an otherwise quiet stretch of beach. With only the odd visits from a fruit seller, come to Bijilo…From£719ppMost popular Gambia hotel dealsRomantic HotelSenegambia Beach HotelKololi, Gambia1,826 reviews Was £1,738From£839ppSave 4%£59 pp depositBadala Park HotelKotu, Gambia435 reviews Was £1,411From£689ppSave 3%£59 pp depositBaobab Holiday ResortBijilo, Gambia110 reviewsFrom£719pp£59 pp depositSunset BeachKotu, Gambia660 reviews Was £2,106From£1,029ppSave 3%African Princess Beach HotelKotu, Gambia313 reviews Was £2,178From£1,029ppSave 6%£59 pp depositRomantic HotelKairaba HotelKololi, Gambia1,039 reviews Was £1,911From£919ppSave 4%£59 pp depositBungalow Beach HotelKotu, Gambia1 review Was £1,631From£799ppSave 3%£59 pp depositView all Gambia hotel dealsYour guide to Gambia holidaysAt a glanceWe loveHoliday typesAt a glanceThings to do in GambiaGambia offers something for everyone, from stunning beaches for sunseekers to lush national parks teeming with wildlife for nature enthusiasts. Water babies can enjoy kayaking while foodies won’t want to miss the sights and tastes of Gambian markets.Explore Kunta Kinteh Island: Take a boat trip to this UNESCO World Heritage Site (and ancestral home of the fictional character, Kunta Kinte, from the novel Roots). Learn about the island's dark history as a former slave trading post and see the ruins of the old fort.Discover Bijilo Forest Park: Wander through this lush coastal forest reserve, home to troops of vervet and red colobus monkeys. Keep an eye out for monitor lizards, over 100 bird species and the park's towering silk cotton trees – some over 200 years old!Relax on Sanyang Beach: Escape the crowds at this pristine stretch of golden sand fringed by coconut palms. Take a dip in the warm Atlantic waters, watch the fishermen bring in their catch or simply soak up the laid-back vibes of this unspoiled coastal gem.Visit Wassu Stone Circles: Marvel at these ancient megalithic structures dating back to 500-1000 AD. The purpose of the stone circles remains a mystery, but they offer a fascinating glimpse into Gambia's pre-colonial past. The site also has an informative visitor centre.Experience Serekunda Market: Immerse yourself in the sights, sounds and smells of Gambia's largest market. Haggle for fresh produce, colourful textiles and handcrafted souvenirs or simply soak up the vibrant atmosphere. Be sure to try the delicious street food, from grilled fish to spicy domoda stew.Gambia beachesThe Gambia has an 80km-long coastline, making it perfect for beach holidays. Pack your swimsuit for our top choices:Kololi Beach: Golden sands and crystal-clear waters make Kololi a popular choice. Lined with beach bars, restaurants and hotels, it's a lively spot to soak up the sun, try water sports or enjoy a sundowner. The beach is well-maintained and safe for swimming.Kotu Beach: Just south of Kololi, Kotu offers a more chilled-out vibe. This wide, sandy beach is fringed by palm trees and has fewer crowds. It's a great spot for a quiet stroll or to watch the fishermen bring in their catch.Sanyang Beach: Escape the resorts at this unspoiled stretch of coast. Sanyang feels a world away, with its deserted sands, sleepy village and cool beach bars. It's a popular spot for surfing and fishing, with a relaxed, hippie vibe.Bijilo Beach: Backed by the Bijilo Forest Park, this secluded beach offers golden sands and plenty of shade. It's a quiet alternative to the main resort beaches, popular with locals and visitors looking to kick back. The nearby forest is home to monkeys and birdlife.Brufut Beach: Wide, golden shores stretch for miles at Brufut, one of Gambia's most stunning beaches. It's a great place for a long walk, with a handful of local beach bars to stop at along the way. The sunsets here are particularly spectacular.We loveFood of GambiaGambian cuisine is a delicious fusion of African, Middle Eastern and European influences. From hearty one-pot dishes like benachin and domoda to tangy yassa and nourishing superkanja, the flavours of Gambia are sure tempt any foodie.Benachin: This 1-pot rice dish is a staple in Gambian cuisine. Cooked with fish or meat, vegetables and tomato paste, it's a hearty meal bursting with flavour. Head to the beach bars of Kololi for some of the best benachin around.Domoda: A deliciously rich groundnut stew, domoda is made with beef, chicken or fish simmered in a sauce of peanut butter, tomatoes and spices. Serekunda Market is the place to go for an authentic taste of this national dish.Yassa: Yassa is a tangy chicken or fish dish marinated in lemon juice, onions and mustard. Grilled over an open fire, it's a smoky and zesty taste sensation. Try it at the roadside stalls near Banjul's Albert Market.Afra: These fluffy deep-fried dough balls are a popular breakfast food or snack. Served with a spicy dipping sauce, they're the perfect pick-me-up at any time of day. Grab a bag from the vendors at Bakau Craft Market.Superkanja: This nourishing okra stew is packed with beef, fish and vegetables in a thick, green sauce. It's a comforting and healthy dish that's popular across the country. For a top-notch superkanja, try the local restaurants around Serrekunda.Adventure holidays in The GambiaGambia offers thrilling adventures for adrenaline lovers. Trek through jungles to spot chimpanzees, kayak in serene wetlands, go off-road cycling in national parks, abseil down sea cliffs or try deep-sea fishing for barracuda!Chimpanzee Trekking in River Gambia National Park: Embark on an unforgettable adventure into the heart of the jungle to spot our closest living relatives in their natural habitat. Led by expert guides, you’ll trek through lush rainforest and observe the playful antics of these fascinating primates up close.Kayaking through the Tanbi Wetlands: Paddle your way through a labyrinth of mangroves, spotting rare birds and wildlife as you go. This tranquil network of creeks and lagoons is a hidden treasure, offering a unique look at Gambia’s beauty.Off-road Cycling in Niumi National Park: Get off-the-beaten-track on an exhilarating bike ride through rugged terrain. Navigate dirt tracks and forest trails, passing remote villages and sweeping coastal vistas. With plenty of opportunities for animal sightings along the way, it's a thrilling way to explore.Abseiling down Baboon Cliffs: Test your nerve with a heart-pumping abseil down these towering sea cliffs. Under the guidance of experienced instructors, you'll descend 50m to the beach below, enjoying breathtaking views of the Atlantic.Deep Sea Fishing off the coast of Tanji: Set sail on a traditional pirogue for an unforgettable day of fishing on the open ocean. With local fishermen as your guides, you'll have the chance to catch barracuda, grouper and snapper, and maybe even see dolphins and whales from the boat.Holiday typesFamily holidays to The GambiaWith its warm hospitality, delicious cuisine and wealth of child-friendly activities, this small West African nation promises an unforgettable adventure for all ages. Be sure to check out our family-friendly favourites:Tanji Village Museum: Step back in time at this open-air museum showcasing traditional Gambian life. Kids will love exploring the replica compounds, trying their hand at crafts like tie-dyeing and weaving, and learning about local customs from friendly guides.Makasutu Culture Forest: Embark on a pirogue ride through the mangroves of this lush reserve. Spot monkeys, monitor lizards and colourful birds along the way, then visit the cultural centre to see traditional dance performances and wood-carving demonstrations.Tanji Fishing Village: Watch the colourful pirogues bring in their catch and see the women processing the fish at this energetic coastal village. Kids can help carry the baskets of fish and learn about the importance of fishing to the community.Brikama Craft Market: Wander through the stalls of this vibrant market, where artisans create beautiful textiles, wood carvings and pottery. Children can try their hand at batik printing or drumming, and pick up some unique souvenirs to take home.Bakau Botanical Gardens: Let the kids run wild in these tranquil gardens, home to towering silk cotton trees, chattering birds and butterflies. Pack a picnic and enjoy a leisurely lunch on the lawns, or take a guided tour to learn about the flora and fauna.Couples holidays to The GambiaThe Gambia offers a whole new world of romantic escape for couples. From private river cruises to secluded beach picnics, there are plenty of opportunities to spend quality time together in this tropical paradise.Sunset Cruise on the River Gambia: Sip champagne and watch the sun dip below the horizon on a romantic river cruise. Spot birds and wildlife along the banks as you glide past mangroves and fishing villages. The tranquil waters and stunning scenery make for an intimate-feeling experience.Couples Spa Day at Coco Ocean Resort: Unwind with a side-by-side massage, followed by a dip in the infinity pool overlooking the ocean at this luxurious beachfront resort. The serene atmosphere and attentive service will leave you feeling refreshed and reconnected.Private Beach Picnic at Tujering: Escape the crowds with a secluded beach picnic. Your private guide will lead you to a hidden cove where you can swim, sunbathe and enjoy a gourmet lunch. It's the perfect way to spend quality time together in a stunning setting.Sunset Horseback Ride at Fajara: Canter along the beach at sunset on a guided horseback ride. No experience is necessary, and the gentle horses are well-suited for beginners. As the sky turns pink and orange, you'll create magical memories together.Cooking Class at Yabouy Home Cooking: Learn the secrets of Gambian cuisine with a private cooking class for couples. Shop for ingredients at the local market, then prepare authentic dishes like benachin and domoda under the guidance of a skilled chef. Savour your creations together in a candlelit garden setting.Your Gambia questions answeredWhere is The Gambia?Is The Gambia a good holiday destination?When is the best time to visit The Gambia?Where is The Gambia?The Gambia is a small country located in West Africa. It’s the smallest country on the African mainland and is surrounded by Senegal on all sides except for a short coastline on the Atlantic Ocean.The Gambia is situated on the banks of the River Gambia, which flows through the centre of the country.Is The Gambia a good holiday destination?Yes, The Gambia is an excellent holiday destination, especially if you’re seeking a unique and memorable experience in West Africa.Known for its stunning Atlantic coastline, the nation boasts pristine beaches perfect for sunbathing and water sports. Wildlife enthusiasts will appreciate the diverse birdlife and opportunities for river safaris along the Gambia River, and the warm, welcoming locals and their rich culture add depth to any visit. While luxury resorts are available, budget-friendly options are on the cards too.When is the best time to visit The Gambia?The dry season, which runs from October to June, are the best months to visit The Gambia, as you’ll experience great temperatures and low levels of humidity.Gambia weatherJan30°CAvg. scraped_itos.title: Destinations - Gambia - Luxotour
scraped_itos.content: Luxotour/Africa/Gambia GambiaOfficially the Islamic Republic of the Gambia, it is a nation in West Africa. It is completely surrounded by Senegal, except at the mouth of the Gambia River into the Atlantic Ocean. Its capital is Banjul, although the largest city in the country is Serekunda. The country is located on the banks of the Gambia River, which gives its name to the country, and which runs through its center and empties into the Atlantic Ocean. The country has an area of 10,500 km² and an estimated population of 1.7 million people. The Gambia shares with the rest of the nations of West Africa a past associated with the slave market, which It was the key factor for the location and maintenance of a colony on the Gambia River, first maintained by the Portuguese and later by the British Empire. On February 18, 1965, The Gambia achieved independence from the United Kingdom and since then the country has enjoyed relative political stability, with the exception of a short period of military dictatorship in 1994.It is a country with very fertile lands that have turned agriculture into one of the key elements of its economy, along with fishing and tourism.Programs at GambiaSindola and South GambiaBased on 2 or 3 passengers traveling together.7 nightsWhat to see in Gambia?Makasutu ForestIn the west of the country, there is the Makasutu Cultural Forest, which stands out for its natural variety and the living culture found there.Makasutu Park is a lush green space where you can find various types of nature such as mangroves, a mature and dense tropical forest, typical Guinean forests, savanna and grasslands. The reserve is open to the public for cultural and tourist tours during the day, which has made it one of the greatest local attractions.On a day tour of this park it is possible to enjoy various cultural displays such as traditional dances of the Jola tribe, some singing accompanied by drums and a traditional Gambian meal at the local restaurant. It is also possible to take canoe tours through the mangroves, as well as learn about traditional herbal remedies and even go bird watching on the salt flats along the river.Kiang National ParkKiang West National Park is one of the largest and most important wildlife reserves in The Gambia. It was declared a National Park in 1987 and is managed by the Gambia Department of Parks and Wildlife Management.The park covers an area of 11,526 hectares and is located on the south bank of the Gambia River, in the Lower River division in Kiang West district. The park headquarters is located in Dumbuto Village, an 18-minute drive from Tendaba Village. The Gambia River marks the northern boundary of the park. Three bolons (streams), Jarin, Jali and Nganingkoi, divide the interior of the park into three sections. The park is unpopulated and there are towns located near its boundaries. Most of the park is located on a low-altitude plateau and is mainly Guinea savannah and dry deciduous forests, and also has salt marshes and mangrove streams.Vegetation types in the park include savanna. Guineana and the dry deciduous forest. Tree species in the park include the baobab, red acacia, Pterocarpus erinaceus, Ceiba pentandra, Terminalia macroptera, Prosopis Africana and Ficus species. The park is an important area for Gambian wildlife, as it is home to individuals of most of the remaining mammal species. These mammals include the African clawless otter, antelope, caracal, common duiker, leopard, swamp mongoose, serval, sitatunga, spotted hyena, wild boars and West African manatee. Reptile species in the park include the African python, Bell's hinged turtle, West African crocodile, Nile monitor (Varanus niloticus), viper, royal python and spitting cobra. The park has more than 300 species of birds, more than half of all bird species recorded in The Gambia. Some of the bird species in the park have a very local distribution and are rarely seen elsewhere in The Gambia. There are 21 birds of prey, including species of eagle, falcon, harrier, falcon and vulture. Other bird species in the park include ten species of kingfisher, the ground hornbill and the endangered brown-necked parrot, which breeds in the park's mangroves.SanyangThe tranquil Sanyang Beach, like the coastal area of the Atlantic Ocean that surrounds it, is called by locals simply Sanyang. The stretch of beach is located in the West Coast region in the Kombo South district.WassuWassu is a community in the interior of the Gambia, owner of Janjang-bureh. The Senegambia Megalithic Circles or Senegambia Stone Circles are located in the Central River Division of the Gambia and the Kaolack Region of Senegal. They consist of four large groups of megalithic circles, formed by stone cylinders, which represent an extraordinary concentration of 1000 monuments. The four groups, Sine Ngayène, Wanar, Wassu and Kerbatch all together add up to 93 stone circles. They cover an area of 9.85 hectares and a protected area of 110.05 hectares.Kunkilling Nature ParkKunkilling Forest Park is a forest park in The Gambia. Established on January 1, 1954, it covers 142 hectares. The forest park is located in a village called Kerr Serrekunda on the southern bank of the Gambia River.prevnextUseful information for traveling to GambiaEntry formalitiesNo visa required. Visitors of Spanish nationality only need to have a valid passport with a minimum validity of six months.LanguageEnglish was the official language of The Gambia until 2014, since then the official language has been Arabic. Although several regional languages are also spoken such as Mandika, Wolof, Fula, Serer in addition to Creole Krio. Due to the regional location, there is a good knowledge of French, which is official in much of West and Central Africa, and is widely spoken in countries in the region.CurrencyThe official currency is the dalasi (GMD), which is divided into 100 bututs. You can exchange currency at the airport and at banks and exchange offices in cities. Traveler's checks issued in euros, US dollars or British pounds can be exchanged upon payment of a fee. MasterCard, American Express and Visa credit cards are accepted in most hotels. Bank hours: Monday to Thursday from 8:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m., Fridays from 8:00 a.m. to 11:00 a.m. Certain banks are open on Saturday mornings.Electricity220V. Plugs are round or square, with three pins. No adapter required.Health preventionsThe yellow fever vaccine is mandatory. Other recommended vaccines: diphtheria, tetanus, poliomyelitis, typhus, hepatitis A and B. It is recommended to follow antimalarial treatment since the country is classified in zone 3. Drink only bottled water. Do not consume raw foods (meat, fish, vegetables, fruits...).ClimateIts climate is tropical, with the months from June to November being the hottest and rainiest and from December to May having cooler and drier weather. Temperatures on the coast are moderate, but they increase inland, becoming very warm in the eastern part of the country.GastronomyTraditional dishes of Gambian cuisine are mostly made from rice (the staple food), with various spicy sauces. However, steamed millet, couscous or cassava are also common.The ingredients that define these dishes are peanut butter (Domoda), okra (okra), palm oil (chew deu terr) or edible leaves such as spinach or cassava leaves. Very popular among poor families is Mbahal, which is rice mixed with grated peanuts and dried fish. Some of the best known typical dishes are Domoda (sauce of peanut butter), supakanja (okra stew), benachin (jolof rice), chere (millet couscous) or chicken yassa (fried chicken in onion).Diferencia horaria con EspañaLa diferencia horaria con España es de -1 hora en invierno y -2 horas en verano.PopulationIt has 1.7 million inhabitants and various ethnic groups such as the Mandingas (41%), the Peuls, the Wolofs, the Soninkes, the Diolas and the Akus. Destinations related to GambiaAfricaCoastal area of Gambiaprevnext

scraped_itos.title: Gambia Urlaub im Westen von Afrika | MEIERS WELTREISEN
scraped_itos.description: Mit MEIERS WELTREISEN Gambia Urlaub in Westafrika buchen und das Land am Strand, im Nationalpark oder beim Besuch der Hauptstadt kennenlernen.
scraped_itos.content: ReisezieleAfrikaGambia UrlaubGambia-Urlaub im vielseitigen WestafrikaVom Strand in die Hauptstadt Banjul und in die MangrovenwälderNur HotelFlug und HotelRundreisenReise findenReise findenReise findenGambia im Westen Afrikas ist das kleinste Land des Kontinents und bekannt für seine reiche Natur. Das Land am gleichnamigen Fluss wird an drei Seiten vom Senegal umschlossen und zieht sich bis zum Atlantik. An der Küste erwarten Sie Sandstrände, während das Landesinnere artenreiche Nationalparks bietet. Auf einer Bootstour können Sie Flusspferde und Krokodile beobachten. Kulturell interessant ist die Hauptstadt Banjul mit dem Nationalmuseum und dem Albert Market. Buchen Sie mit MEIERS WELTREISEN Ihren Gambia-Urlaub nach Ihren individuellen Wünschen.Unterwegs im Urlaub: Gambias Weltkulturerbe und LebensgefühlGambia steht nicht nur für Strand- und Badeurlaub, sondern hat auch kulturell viel zu bieten. Die kleine Insel Kunta Kinteh im Gambia-Fluss gehört zum UNESCO-Weltkulturerbe. Einblicke in das afrikanische Lebensgefühl bieten der Serrekunda Market oder der Albert Market im Zentrum Banjuls.Westafrikanische Kultur im Urlaub in GambiaDa Gambia im Vergleich zu anderen afrikanischen Ländern recht klein ist, können Sie die verschiedenen Facetten des Landes in kurzer Zeit erkunden. Der Gambia-Fluss bietet dafür beste Voraussetzungen: Er durchzieht das Land und beheimatet vielfältige Tier- und Vogelarten. Bootsfahrten auf dem Fluss sind eine gute Gelegenheit, die Tierwelt zu beobachten. Die Mischung aus Stränden entlang der Atlantikküste, historischen Stätten wie James Island und kulturellen Festivals ist eine gute Voraussetzung für einen vielseitigen und authentischen Gambia-Urlaub. Das Land in Westafrika ist auch für seine Gastfreundschaft und freundlichen Einheimischen bekannt.Die Kultur Westafrikas können Sie während Ihrer Gambia-Reise in der Hauptstadt Banjul hautnah erleben. Hier wird auf öffentlichen Plätzen getrommelt und gespielt, Straßenmärkte wie der Serrekunda Market laden zum Flanieren und Entdecken ein. An allen Ecken duftet es nach Gewürzen und Gerichten wie Maafe, einem Eintopf mit Erdnusssoße. Sehenswürdigkeiten wie der Triumphbogen Arch 22 und das Nationalmuseum spiegeln die Geschichte des Staates wider. Sehenswert ist auch der einstige Trinkbrunnen King George Memorial Fountain am Versammlungs- und Sportplatz July 22nd Square.Naturschutzgebiete, Mangroven und Steinkreise: Ausflugsziele für den Urlaub in GambiaIm Gambia-Urlaub gibt es eine ganze Reihe lohnender Ausflugsziele. Eines davon ist der Nationalpark Tanbi Wetland Complex an der Mündung des Flusses Gambia, der mit Mangrovenwäldern und Gezeitenlagunen fasziniert. Affen, Sumpfmangusten und Seekühe sowie Wasser- und Sumpfvögel leben in dem Schutzgebiet. Bei einem Ausflug in das Abuko-Naturschutzgebiet in der Nähe von Kololi am Atlantik können Sie Savannen und Galeriewälder bestaunen. Nicht weit entfernt erwartet Sie mit dem Kachikally Crocodile Pool bei Bakau eine weitere Attraktion. Auch die Steinkreise von Wassu strahlen eine mystische Atmosphäre aus: Mehr als tausend Monumente gehören zu dem UNESCO-Weltkulturerbe, das teils in Gambia, teils im Senegal liegt.Gambia auf einen BlickGambia ist bekannt für seine Sandstrände wie die in Kololi und Bakau, die zum Entspannen und Wassersport einladen.Bei einer Bootsfahrt auf dem Gambia-Fluss können Sie verschiedene Vogelarten beobachten und die historische James Island (heute auch Kuntah Kinteh Island genannt) besuchen.In Gambia gilt das Krokodil als Symbol der Fruchtbarkeit, das in Kultstätten wie dem Kachikally Crocodile Pool verehrt wird.Die beste Reisezeit für Ihren Gambia-UrlaubDie beste Reisezeit für Urlaub in Gambia fällt auf die Winter- und Frühlingsmonate von November bis Mai. In der Trockenzeit sind die Temperaturen mit knapp über 30 °C angenehm warm und es fällt wenig Regen. Mit 9 Sonnenstunden im März ist Gambia ein gutes Reiseziel, um dem kalten Winter zu entfliehen. Auch wenn Sie auf Ihrer Reise Tiere beobachten möchten, ist die Trockenzeit die erste Wahl: Dann versammeln sich die Tiere an den Wasserstellen. Während der Regenzeit kann es zu starkem Niederschlag kommen, insbesondere im August. Sie ist eine gute Zeit für all jene, die die Landschaft der Nationalparks in üppigem Grün erleben möchten.Das Klima für Ihre Gambia-Reise auf einen BlickIn Gambia dauert die Regenzeit von Juni bis Oktober, wobei es vor allem von Juli bis September ausgiebig regnet.Die Trockenzeit dauert von November bis Mai. Die Temperaturen liegen dann bei 31 bis 34 °C.Mit 9 Stunden Sonne am Tag und 34 °C ist der März der wärmste Monat des Jahres in Gambia und ein guter Zeitpunkt für eine Auszeit vom deutschen Winter.Klimatabelle von GambiaMax. TemperaturMin. TemperaturSonnenstundenWassertemperaturRegentageJanuar31 °C15 °C722 °C0Februar32 °C16 °C821 °C0März34 °C17 °C921 °C0April33 °C18 °C822 °C0Mai31 °C20 °C724 °C0Juni31 °C23 °C726 °C5Juli30 °C23 °C627 °C15August29 °C23 °C627 °C17September31 °C23 °C627 °C15Oktober31 °C22 °C727 °C5November32 °C19 °C827 °C0Dezember31 °C16 °C724 °C0Mit einer Pauschalreise nach GambiaFlug, Hotel, Transfers und mehr bekommen Sie unkompliziert aus einer Hand, wenn Sie Ihren Gambia-Urlaub mit MEIERS WELTREISEN buchen. Gambia eignet sich ideal für Pauschalurlaub, da es von Stränden über eine reiche Tierwelt bis hin zu kulturellen Erlebnissen eine breite Palette von Attraktionen bietet.Im Gambia-Urlaub die lokale Kultur kennenlernenIn Gambia bietet sich besonders die Küstenregion entlang des Atlantiks für einen gelungenen Pauschalurlaub an. Der Badeort Kololi ist eine der beliebtesten Destinationen und verfügt über eine Fülle von Hotels und Resorts, die von gemütlichen Unterkünften bis zu gehobenen Premiumhotels reichen. Hier erwarten Sie Sandstrände, Wassersportmöglichkeiten und lebhafte Märkte, die einen Einblick in die lokale Kultur bieten. Die nahegelegenen Orte wie Bakau und Fajara verfügen über Nationalparks und Naturschutzgebiete, wo Sie auf geführten Touren die vielfältige Tierwelt Gambias erkunden können. Pauschalurlaube in Gambia bieten eine Kombination aus Entspannung am Strand, kulturellen Erlebnissen und Naturabenteuern.Kachikally Crocodile Pool: Reise-Tipp für den Gambia-UrlaubDer Kachikally Crocodile Pool bei Bakau, Gambia ist mehr als nur ein Ort, an dem Krokodile leben. Er ist ein heiliger Ort, an dem Besucher die Möglichkeit haben, die Tiere hautnah zu erleben und in die Kultur und Spiritualität Gambias einzutauchen.Gambias mystische Welt: der Kachikally Crocodile Pool bei BakauDer Kachikally Crocodile Pool in der Nähe von Bakau ist eine der Top-Attraktionen in Gambia. Dieser Krokodilteich ist von großer Bedeutung für die lokale Bevölkerung und wird von Krokodilen bewohnt, die als heilig angesehen werden. Im Gambia-Urlaub haben Sie die Gelegenheit, diese beeindruckenden Tiere aus nächster Nähe zu beobachten und mehr über ihre Bedeutung in der Kultur und Mythologie Gambias zu erfahren. Der Pool ist von einem Mangrovenwald umgeben, der einen friedlichen und spirituellen Ort schafft. Der Kachikally Crocodile Pool ist ein Ort, an dem Geschichte, Natur und Kultur miteinander verschmelzen.Die wichtigsten Fragen zu Ihrem Gambia-Urlaub kurz und knapp beantwortetEignet sich Gambia als Reiseziel für einen ersten Afrika-Urlaub?Wie sind die Lebenskosten in Gambia?Wie lange dauert der Flug nach Gambia?Welches ist das beliebteste Reiseziel in Gambia? scraped_itos.title: Wildlife Holidays in The Gambia for 2025/26 - Naturetrek
scraped_itos.description: Professionally organised, expertly guided wildlife holidays and tours to Gambia with Naturetrek – the UK’s leading wildlife tour specialist.
scraped_itos.content: Wildlife Holidays in The Gambia Affectionately known as the’ Smiling Coast of West Africa’, the Republic of The Gambia is a tiny country that packs a mighty avian punch, being home to more than 570 species! A kaleidoscope of colour awaits you on arrival, with parrots, turacos, rollers, bush-shrikes, sunbirds and bee-eaters all vying for your attention, and raptors including Black Kite, Palm-nut Vulture and Beaudouin’s Snake Eagle soaring overhead. Accessed via a direct flight from the UK, and with no time difference, The Gambia is an easily accessible country that offers a combination of superlative bird watching and a warm sunny climate. Speak with our Gambia specialist Barney Jones Operations Manager Email Barney or call 01962 733051 Featured Tours to The Gambia The Gambia in Style An 8-day holiday enjoying the spectacular birdlife and other natural history of ... 8 days | £2,795 The Gambia An 11-day (12-day in 2026) tour to enjoy the superlative, easily accessible bird... 11 days | £3,750 The Gambia in Style - Photography Special A leisurely 8-day, single-centre, photography holiday based at the luxurious and... 8 days | £3,350 View All Tours To The Gambia Our Specialist Recommends "Our ‘Gambia in Style’ holiday is a relaxing week where we enjoy morning and afternoon excursions on foot and by boat, plus two longer day trips to explore further afield, all from a tranquil and relaxing base. I particularly love Mandina’s Floating Lodges, and the chance to watch for Giant Kingfishers from the comfort of your bed!" Operations Manager - Barney Jones Email Barney Naturetrek Tours to The Gambia Between November and April each year we offer monthly departures of our week-long ‘Gambia in Style’ holiday, based at the Mandina Lodges, set in the peaceful Makasutu Forest and bordering the secluded mangrove-lined tributary of the Gambia River. In addition, each October we offer a 12-day ‘bargain birding’ holiday which begins and ends on the coast, and in between visits a number of prime birding locations along the Gambia River. What birds might I see? The range of potential species includes huge Goliath Herons, Pink-backed Pelicans & other waterbirds A splendid variety of raptors African Golden Oriole, White-throated and Little Bee-Eaters, Violet Turaco, Yellow-fronted Tinkerbird, Bearded Barbet On our ‘bargain birding’ tour, the highlight is likely to be the chance to see the handsome Egyptian Plover × Please complete all required fields! scraped_itos.title: Gambia Holidays 2025/26 | Package Holidays to Gambia, West Africa | Olympic Holidays
scraped_itos.description: Year-round sun and palm tree fringed golden sands lapped by the Atlantic Ocean; Gambia holidays are simply idyllic. Discover great value holiday deals today.
scraped_itos.content: The Gambia at a glance The Gambia holidays are simply idyllic, imagine a soft golden sandy beach overlooked by palm trees and lapped by the Atlantic Ocean. Just six hours away, you could be enjoying some winter sunshine sooner than you think. Book your Holiday Airports Approx. 6 hour flight time Travel Time 1 hour behind UK time Time Difference Wildlife, national parks and sandy beaches Book Now Holidays to Gambia Description Looking for a holiday destination with a difference? The Gambia holidays could be just what you're looking for. This small West African country, measuring just over 4,000 square miles is wrapped around the River Gambia and offer an idyllic holiday experience with year round sunshine virtually guaranteed. Gambia can be as busy or as relaxed as you desire, the wonderfully golden beaches,like popular Kololi Beach are very welcoming and ready made for sunbathing. If you're in the mood to explore you'll be spoilt for choice with beautiful landscapes, fascinating history and culture. There's plenty to discover. Imagine a 30 mile stretch of superb beaches with soft golden sands, overlooked by palm trees and lapped by the Atlantic Ocean. Book Gambia holidays and you'll experience traditional culture and a landscape that has remained largely unspoilt by tourism. Gambia holidays provide a wonderful opportunity to see some of the wonders Africa has to offer including lush vegetation and exotic wildlife as well as fabulous beaches. The best of all worlds on your African adventure. One of the best things about holidays to The Gambia though, especially if you tend to suffer from jet lag, is you can be by lapping up the gorgeous sunshine in no time at all. Gambia is in the same time zone as the UK and is only a six hour flight, making it even more attractive as a holiday destination. The Gambia is one of the smallest African countries with a rich heritage and is ideal for winter sun holidays. The people of The Gambia possess a genuine willingness to help and Africa's oldest English speaking county offers visitors a truly warm welcome. This friendly country is teeming with vibrant markets and merchants trading against a backdrop of colonial architecture - a throwback to the British occupation in the 18th and 19th centuries. Discover the vibrancy of Bakau, Serrekunda and the capital, Banjul, which is as colourfully African as you might imagine. The beach town of Kololi is one of Gambia’s most popular places to visit. Spend long days leisurely lolling on the golden sands before exploring “the Strip,” Kololi’s main thoroughfare, lined with restaurants, hotels and nightclubs. Brave the bush on a guided safari, chatter with the monkeys of Bijilo Forest Park and bargain for handmade treasures at the Senegambia Craft Market. During the day, fish for Barracuda on the Atlantic Ocean, strike a bargain in one of the many markets and in the evening, sample the wide variety of Gambian and international cuisine. Dine on freshly caught seafood including ladyfish, barracuda, snapper, butterfish, lobster and huge Atlantic prawns. Gambia hotels offer a quality dining experience and most hotels offer some form of evening entertainment, varying from a single kora player to a lively stage show or an African dance troupe. Las Vegas it isn't, but there is a casino and there are a number of bars and clubs that stay open until the early hours - these are located mainly in Kololi. In the evenings, you will have the choice of staying within your hotel or enjoying dinner and drinks in the wide range of restaurants and bars either nearby or a short taxi ride away. Gambia is fast gaining an international reputation with a wide choice of restaurants from casual beach bars to formal gourmet dining, serving a range of cuisine from Italian to Lebanese. During your holiday, souvenirs can be bought in Banjul at the craft market across from MacCarthy Square and at Bengdulalu. One of the most popular purchases is the Gambishirt, made of printed and embroidered cotton cloth, mostly in bright colours. Popular items purchased by those taking holidays in Gambia include wood carvings, beaded belts, silver and gold jewellery and ladies handbags are also popular items. The Gambia holidays are a journey into a tropical oasis with a wide range of activities to keep you occupied and to suit even the most discerning traveller. If you're in search of an all inclusive holiday, a family holiday or in need of some winter sunshine, then a holiday to Gambia could be the perfect choice. Things To Do The Gambia Holidays - Excursions Make your Gambia holidays extra special and book one of our wonderful excursions. Carefully selected to cater for everyone's interests, here's just a few of our most popular excursions to tempt you. Your holiday can be a memorable one from river cruising, fishing, village tours, to African wrestling, bird watching, trekking, horse and camel riding, and adventure trips. Musical events, evening entertainment, cultural orientation, and sporting events. Jeep Safari: Not like any other jeep safari you might have been on. When all the pick-ups are done we depart for Sukuta (which means "new settlement" in Madinka) to see the local market and mosque. Your drive then takes you through farming areas and forest parks and a stop is made to walk through the forest, where monkeys maybe seen. We then proceed to the beach for lunch where you can relax, soak up some of the sun and have a swim for a couple of hours. Driving back along the coast is a beautiful site and you pass by many fishing villages, one being Tanje one of the busiest in the area. Here you see the men taking in their daily catch and the women gathering and cleaning the fish. 3-Day Mini Safari: An early start begins with a drive to Makasutu Cultural forest. On this trip water birds, mud skippers, fiddler crabs, green velvet monkeys and women collecting oysters by the shore can all be seen while taking in the great views this part of Gambia has to offer. During your trip to Makasutu you have the option to visit the craft market, where carvings, sculptures, textiles and other African artifacts can be seen and purchased. The following day we proceed to Tendaba camp. On arrival a boat trip is organised on the "bolongs" which are the tributaries of the River Gambia. You then head back to Sindola Camp for relaxation and a chance to freshen up by the pool, and dinner is followed by a magnificent traditional Jola dance that will be one of the highlights of your trip. Nature Explorer: Gambia is considered to be a paradise for birdwatchers. This is a trip which starts in the early hours of the morning and first takes us to Lamin Lodge, which is located on the famous Lamin Creek. After drinks we get into dug out canoes and silently paddle through the creeks, trying not to disturb the birds and surrounding nature. This is truly a relaxing and enjoyable trip as the water and creeks are so calm and peaceful at this time of the day. The trip on the creeks lasts about 1 hour 30 minutes, after which we head back to Lamin Lodge. Following breakfast we rejoin the coach and head to Abuko Nature Reserve. At the Nature Reserve you go on a forest walk and observation. You also visit a traditional educational centre, while passing an abidance of wildlife and plants. These are just a few of the exciting days and nights out available from your representative in resort. We strongly advise you to confirm your place at the Welcome Get Together as places are limited and we don't want you to miss out. Things To See City Sights: A visit to the capital city, Banjul, to experience the hustle and bustle of the main market and learn about the local batik art and tie-dye crafts. Southern Gambia: This is a great way to experience the real Gambia taking a trip aboard Swiss army trucks, heading south towards the border with Senegal. A real forage through the bush, passing local villages where children will welcome you with songs from the past. After lunch there is chance to swim from a deserted beach before visiting the largest fishing project in the area. Cape Point: A small resort on the West coast, Cape Point's key attraction is a long golden beach. Visit the local market and pick up a bargain or two and if you travel a little further then you will com to the Botanical Gardens - created in colonial times and ideal for wildlife spotting. Kotu: This tranquil resort boasts a lovely sandy beach with relaxing bars to while away the day. Kololi is just a short taxi ride away if you want more choice of bars and restaurants. Top hotels in The Gambia Ocean Bay Hotel and Resort The Gambia Cape Point Senegambia Beach Hotel Plus The Gambia Kololi Sunset Beach Hotel The Gambia Kotu Transport Taxis: Local taxis are widely available, with fares depending on the distance and duration of the trip. 'Town taxis' are painted yellow and are used mostly for local trips around Banjul and the Atlantic coast resorts. 'Tourist taxis' are painted green and can go anywhere in the country. Most hotels have Taxi ranks outside. Climate Best time to go to The Gambia Located midway between the Tropic of Cancer and the Equator, The Gambia enjoys virtually uninterrupted sunshine and high daytime temperatures with almost no rainfall from the month of November and all the way to June. On the coast, The Gambia experiences only mild fluctuations in temperature from winter to summer. Date last updated: 09 May 2025

scraped_itos.description: Cheap Holidays to Gambia, including All inclusive Holidays to The Gambia. Super-Low Deposits from £30pp. ATOL Protected.
scraped_itos.content: The Gambia HolidaysEnjoy our lowest-priced travel months!View dealsDestination or HotelAnywhereDestination or HotelAnywhereListDeparture AirportAll AirportsDeparture AirportAll AirportsTravel DatesSelect DateTravel DatesSelect DateNights7 nightsNights7 nightsI’m flexible with dates +/- 3 daysGuests2 Adult, 1 RoomGuests2 Adult, 1 RoomSearchHoliday FinderNewCity BreaksHotel OnlyDestination or HotelAnywhereDestination or HotelAnywhereListDeparture AirportAll AirportsDeparture AirportAll AirportsTravel DatesSelect DateTravel DatesSelect DateNights7 nightsNights7 nightsI’m flexible with dates +/- 3 daysGuests2 Adult, 1 RoomGuests2 Adult, 1 RoomSearchOverviewThings To DoTravel AdviceDiscover the amazing wildlife and blissful beaches of The Gambia. With non-stop warm weather and fantastic hospitality, you can relax here all year round.Get ready to experience a treasure trove of alluring beaches, vibrant markets, and lively festivals - we're talking about The Gambia! Tucked inside Senegal, this cheeky little West African gem has an infectious energy that will sweep you off your feet. If you’re hunting for your next exotic holiday destination, you've come to the right place.Ding, ding, ding! Here are some absolute corkers, the best of Gambia's highlights:Smashing sunsets over the River GambiaHaggling for treats at the bustling Albert MarketSpotting colourful birds at Abuko Nature ReserveExploring the rustic charm of the Makasutu Cultural ForestMarvelling at the haunting Kunta Kinteh IslandWhat are the best beaches in The Gambia?Fancy yourself a bit of a beach bum, do ya? Perfect, because Gambia has sandy stretches that will make your heart skip a beat! Kololi Beach: It's the heart of the sun-kissed strip, buzzing with beach bars and water sports.Kotu Beach: The perfect chill-out spot, famous for its sunset views and beachside eateries.Cape Point Beach: Tranquil and pristine, great for long beach walks and birdwatching.Bijilo Beach: Nestled near the Bijilo Forest Park, it's a great place for wildlife spotting.Bakau: Colourful boats and a buzzing fish market make this beach.Batokunku: The undisturbed flat sands of this peaceful beach line up with the horizon to create the perfect sunset scene.Read MoreWeather in The GambiaJAN24°CFEB26°CMAR26°CAPR27°CMAY27°CJUN28°CJUL28°CAUG27°CSEP27°COCT27°CNOV26°CDEC25°CThe Gambia enjoys virtually uninterrupted sunshine and high temperatures all year round. There are 2 distinct seasons, wet and dry.From July to October the temperatures rise combined with sharp showers, but these occur mainly at night.The best time to visit is between November and March when it's dry and warm.View destination on a mapFAQsHow long does it take to fly to The Gambia?It takes about six and a half hours to fly to The Gambia from the UK. What’s the time difference between the UK and The Gambia?The Gambia is one hour behind the time in the UK. What currency do they use in The Gambia?The official currency of The Gambia is the Gambian Dalasi.What language do they speak in The Gambia?The official language of The Gambia is English. Get those comfy shoes on, because we’ve got a list that's brimming with adventures! The capital city, Banjul, is home to the famed Arch 22 and the African Heritage Museum – a day here and you’ll be buzzing with excitement. For a bit of local life, head to Serrekunda, Gambia's largest town, where colourful markets and busy streets promise an experience like no other. And don't forget to take a leisurely boat ride down the River Gambia, where you can spot monkeys, hippos, and if you're really lucky, even dolphins! And that’s not in why not try one of these…Take a river cruise along the Gambia River for splendid views.Birdwatchers, head to Tanji Bird Reserve.Dare to wrestle? Visit a local village and learn traditional Gambian wrestling.Try your hand at fishing in the clear waters of the Atlantic.Visit a local school or join a drumming and dance class for cultural immersion.What events can I go to in The Gambia?If you're one for festivals, Gambia's vibrant events will leave you speechless! The International Roots Festival, a biannual event, celebrates African culture and heritage with music, dance, and art. Or if you fancy a fish fiesta, check out the International Roots Festival (biennial): A week-long celebration of African culture and heritage.Banjul Demba Cultural Festival (December): Features traditional music, dance, and local cuisine.Kanilai International Cultural Festival (June): A vibrant showcase of traditional music, dance, and sporting events.Tanji Village Fish Smokey: Although this happens throughout the year, we thought it deserved a spot here: a look at the traditional method of fish smoking. You'll have a whale of a time!Where's the best nightlife in The Gambia?Fancy a bit of moonlit mischief? Well, Gambia's nightlife has you covered! Think lively beach bars, bustling local dance floors and sultry night markets. Sink your toes in the sand at a beach shack like Poco Loco in Kololi and sway to the beat of African drums while the stars twinkle above. Or, get your dancing shoes on and hit the vibrant clubs in Senegambia strip. We're talking lively beats, infectious laughter and a dance-off or two, Gambia style. Fancy a flutter? Check out the casino in Kololi. And don't forget the lively night markets - they're a hoot! As the sun dips, watch Gambia come alive with energy that's nothing short of contagious.What’s the food like in The Gambia?If there’s one thing Gambians know how to do, it's how to whip up some mouth-watering grub. Dig into a bowl of Domoda, a hearty peanut stew, or sample the national dish, Benachin, a spicy rice and fish combo that will tickle your taste buds. And, if you've got a sweet tooth, you can't miss the Tapalapa bread, a sweet and crusty delight that's perfect for an afternoon snack. Don't forget to wash it down with baobab juice or palm wine!Ready to tuck into some Gambian grub or hit the town? Check out some of our top-spots.Ngala Lodge Restaurant in Bakau: Fine dining with an ocean view.Calypso Beach Bar & Restaurant at Kololi Beach: Chill vibe and local delicacies.Yosh's in Kotu: Vegan-friendly options and live music.Solomon’s Beach Bar & Restaurant at Cape Point: Great seafood and stunning views.The Green Mamba Garden in Kololi: Pub-style food with a tropical garden backdrop.Key facts about The GambiaFlight time6.5 hrsTime Difference-1 hrCurrencyGambian DalasiLanguageEnglishWill COVID-19 affect my holiday to The Gambia?We are currently closely following the COVID-19 situation and how it affects travel. You can find out the most up to date information about travel to Greece on the FCDO website.Do I need any vaccinations to visit The Gambia?Please check with your healthcare provider for all up to date vaccination advice before booking your holiday.Do I need to pay tourist tax on my holiday to The Gambia?There is currently no tourist tax to pay in The Gambia.Observing RamadanThe Islamic holy month of Ramadan ended on 30/03/2025. The next time Ramadan will occur is between 17/02/2026 and 18/03/2026. During this time, eating, drinking and smoking may be restricted to the hours between sunset and sunrise, and visitors may be expected to observe these practices in public spaces as a sign of respect, meaning some cafés and restaurants will close during the day, restrictions on alcohol sales may be in place, and hotel dining for non-Muslim guests may take place in private rooms. Playing music, dancing, and eating in public areas may also be restricted during this time.HDHi, I'm Holly Day!I can help you plan your trip to The Gambia

scraped_itos.content: GambiaTime Difference: EST +5 hours Current Time and Date in The Gambia Currency: Currency Converter – Gambian Dalasi (GMD) Travel Advisory: State Department Report for The Gambia US embassy in The Gambia: banjul.usembassy.gov The Gambia is the smallest country in Africa with an approximate area of 11,000 km2 and is situated around the Gambia River which flows into the Atlantic Ocean. The Gambia is surrounded by Senegal along its entire 740km border. The capital city is Banjul although most of the country’s 1.7 million people leave in Serekendu and Brikama, the two major cities. A former colony of the Portuguese then the British. The Gambia was the first trade site for the Europeans due to its ideal location on the Gambia River. Health: CDC The Gambia What to Pack Weather: The Gambia Weather Travel Requirements Passport Visa required for all US Passport holders. If you are not a US Passport holder please contact the embassy in your region Proof of vaccination against yellow fever Diplomatic Missions Embassy of The Gambia in Washington D.C. Official website of the embassy of The Gambia in Washington D.C. Permanent Mission of the Gambia to the United Nations Official website of the Permanent Mission of the Gambia to the United Nations in New York City List of all embassies, high commissions, and consulates of The Gambia Addresses and contact information of all diplomatic missions of The Gambia Climate Wet Season: June to October; Average high temperature of 86°F and low of 73°F Dry Season: November-May; Average high temperature of 75°F and low of 60°F Communications: Dial 011 followed by country code 220 Language: English is the official language. African languages widely spoken are Wolof and Mandeka UNESCO World Heritage Sites Kunta Kinteh Island and Related Sites This site showcases the different phases and facets African-European relations from the 15th-18th centuries and an important tangible reminder of the slave trade era. Kunta Kinteh Island is in the Gambia River which was the first trade route to inland Africa. The site also contains remains of European Settlements including forts and batteries and well as historical villages. Stone circles of Senegambia This site contains four large groups of stone circles that include 1000 monuments which are stretched along the River Gambia. The remains suggest a sacred landscape which was created over more than 1500 years between 3rd Century BC and 16th Century AD and signal the existence of a highly organized and prosperous society.
